hits.name: Camel's Hump Trail
hits.description:
Camel's Hump Trail is one of the best day hiking trails in the Green Mountain National Forest, along with being the third highest peak in the state. The summit offers unbeatable views in every direction, including Killington Peak. The trailhead can be accessed off of Camel’s Hump Road, where there is a small parking area for visitors. Users recommend arriving early in the warmer months and on weekends, since the road is not an option for parking.

This trail can be completed as an out-and-back hike, which is 6 miles round trip via the Monroe Trail, or a loop route via Monroe Trail, Dean Trail, and Long Trail. Alternatively, Camel's Hump can also be reached from the Burrows trailhead via the Forest City Trail to Burrows Trail.

For this out-and-back route, users will start the hike on the Monroe trail which is steep, but does include plenty of leveling off during the hike. From the Monroe Trail users will reach the Dean Trail intersection, at which point users have the option to turn left onto Dean Trail and then take the Long Trail up to the summit or continue straight on the Monroe Trail to the summit. If continuing straight on Monroe Trail, users will reach the hut clearing at which point the Monroe Trail ends and becomes the Long Trail. It is then a short climb to the summit.

The last part of the hike can become very steep and narrow. If afraid of heights this may not be the trail for shaky legs. But, the fear is worth it once reached the summit, as users have a 360 degree view of nearly every mountain range in the area. You will see Mount Mansfield to the north and Mount Washington to the east. On a clear day you can even see Canada!

From the summit, take the Long Trail south back to the Monroe Trail. To enjoy the descent and get a pat on the back!

hits.name: Mount Mansfield Loop Trail
hits.description:
Mount Mansfield is the highest mountain in Vermont and is located in Chittenden County within the Green Mountains. The Mount Mansfield Loop Trail takes you above the tree line. The hike begins at Underhill State Park off of Mountain Road where there is plenty of parking available in the parking lot for a fee of $4/person. Because the park has tent camping, there are bathrooms and potable water available at the trailhead. 

The hike starts along CCC Road. You will continue on CCC Road until you reach Maple Ridge Trail. Maple Ridge Trail is the most technical part of the hike. Two parts of the Maple Ridge Trail stand out as scariest. One is a rock wall that has only limited grips and toe holds, and a fall off that wall would cause serious harm. The second part is a chasm about six feet deep that you have to leap over. As with climbing the rock wall, there is no margin for error with this leap. You have to commit and then execute properly. The average adult may find it frightening but will be able to do it safely. Because of these two challenging sections, it is not recommend to attempt this hike in bad weather conditions where the rocks would be wet or icy. You will then reach the Long Trail and continue along the Long Trail north, passing the forehead, the nose and northward along the ridgeline to the Chin. From there, you can extend the trip up to Adams Apple or turn around and begin the descent along the Sunset Ridge Trail. 

The is a great hike to Vermont's highest point that boasts spectacular views once you get to the rocky outcrops on the Maple Ridge Trail and will continue to impress on the Long Trail and for most of the descent on the Sunset Ridge Trail. Mount Mansfield is also one of two places in Vermont where Alpine Tundra can be found. Some additional popular options in this area are the Laura Cowles Trail, Lake Champlain, and the Taft Lodge. This is one of the best trails in the state of Vermont.

hits.name: Lye Brook Falls Trail
hits.description: Lye Brook Falls in Lye Brook Wilderness is a popular hiking destination just outside of Manchester. The hiking trail, marked with blue blazes, starts at the Lye Brook Falls Trailhead and follows Lye Brook Trail for just under 2 miles before curving off to the right along Lye Brook Falls Trail. The route is well-marked, incredibly clean and easy to navigate. The last part of the trail up to the falls is uphill but the effort is worth it. The views of the 125 foot waterfall, one of the highest in the state of Vermont, is a treat. There is room for 20 cars in the parking lot with additional parking along the road. Please practice Leave No Trace principles in this sensitive wilderness area.

hits.name: Sunset Ridge and Long Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Sunset Ridge and Long Trail Loop is one of the most popular trails in the Underhill State Park. The Underhill Center and parking lot are right at the trailhead. The Sunset Ridge trail takes you to the highest peak of the park while the Long Trail loops along the ridge back to the trailhead. 

It's recommended by park staff to ascend the Halfway House Trail, traverse the Long Trail to the Chin (highest point in Vermont) and then descend Sunset Ridge. Halfway House is a steep trail, especially close to the Long Trail ridge-line, but has numerous switchbacks along the way. The Long Trail is all above the tree line and provides nearly 360 views of Vermont, Adirondacks, & White Mountains, but there's no shelter in bad weather (wind or rain). Sunset Ridge is a more gradual hike down, so it's less difficult heading down Mansfield; it also is above tree line for the top half and provides excellent views of the Champlain Valley and Adirondacks. The trail to the summit can be slippery and spikes are recommended. 

Other popular sites in the area are the Green Mountains, Cantilever Rock, and Pleasant Valley. 

Halfway and Sunset Ridge have Blue Blazes, while the Long Trail is White. It's best to avoid Yellow blazed trails because they are generally more difficult rock scrambles.

hits.name: Sterling Pond Trail
hits.description:
During the week or early in the morning, this pond is beyond idyllic featuring subalpine plants, wildlife and quiet water. Starting off directly across from the info station at the parking lot, the first quarter mile is saturated with carefully built stone steps. Much of the first three quarters of a mile is lined with deciduous forest, trickling water and everything else you would expect in a wild area. Those unaccustomed to rocky and uneven surfaces may be interested in something with a bit of ankle support. 

The climb itself is not unforgiving, like the Hell Brook trail or the Long Trail up Mansfield, as climbing comes in bursts and flats are thrown in often. It's a good starter hike. Once you reach the Long Trail, turn left and within a tenth of a mile, you will approach the pond area. Note though that this area has a very limited growing season and despite what many folks may do due to inadequate signage, one should not approach the pond or walk in the grass; stay on the trail and the rocks to protect this landmark for years and generations to come.

hits.name: Killington Peak via Bucklin Trail
hits.description: This is a hike up to Killington Peak where there are far-reaching panoramic views to the Green Mountains of Vermont, the Adirondacks of New York, and the White Mountains of New Hampshire. The first two miles of the route are very easy with gradual incline, but the upper section before the summit becomes steep and difficult. The trailhead is accessible in the winter, but hikers should bring crampons, snowshoes or microspikes for traction on the upper half of the mountain.

hits.name: Moss Glen Falls Trail and VAST 100 Trail
hits.description: For most people, the highlight of this hike is the actual Moss Glen Falls, which is only about 1/4 mile from the trailhead. This route is labeled as being "easy", but there is a short steep climb required to get to the best falls viewpoint. The rest of the route follows an old woods road. At about the 1.5 mile mark (just after a wooden bridge), this road turns left and begins a steep ascent, which actually reaches a (viewless) summit after the end of the marked route.

hits.name: Equinox Mountain and Lookout Rock
hits.description: Being the highest mountain in the Taconic Range, the climb to the top of Equinox Mountain is steep and unrelenting. At the summit, you'll find a visitor's center and a monastery that can also be accessed by car. Lookout Rock is another two tenths of a mile from the summit, which has views of nearby Manchester Village, as well as a unique and beautiful marble bench.

hits.name: Camel's Hump Loop via Burrows Trail
hits.description:
This 4,083 foot peak has a very unique summit cone that gives it its name.  You'll be following the Burrows Trail through Camel's Hump State Park for just over 5 miles round trip.  Right before you reach the summit you'll come to the junction of the Long Trail which you will follow up the steep cone to the summit.  From there you can continue down Long Trail to Forest City Trail, or return the way you came. 

Hikers recommend doing the loop via Long Trail/Forest City in a counter-clockwise direction. Start at the Burrows trailhead, follow the Forest City Connector and Forest City to Long Trail, then go left on Long Trail up to the summit from the south. Heading in the opposite direction from the summit down Long Trail is treacherous in places.

hits.name: The Nose to The Chin via Long Trail
Stowe Pinnacle via Pinnacle Meadow Trail
hits.description: The Pinnacle Meadow Trail starts at the Pinnacle Meadows parking area and connects with the Stowe Pinnacle Trail leading up to Stowe Pinnacle.

hits.name: Mount Elmore
hits.description:
The trailhead begins to the right of the lot.

There is a $4 parking fee for day use.

hits.name: Mount Mansfield via Hellbrook Trail and the Long Trail
hits.description:
The Hell Brook trail is a fun and challenging route to 'The Chin' of Mount Mansfield (The Summit). This is the shortest and steepest but also most technically difficult route to the summit.

The trail is mostly large rocks and is usually wet. This route is considerably less busy than the popular Long Trail, which also makes it nice.

hits.name: Bromley Mountain Via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
The Chin via Long and Profanity Trail
hits.description: Parking is near the Stowe Mountain Resort Gondola Ride. Look for the Lower Barnes Lot on Google. When you head into the area, take the first Right. Trail head is across the street. This add some distance to the whole hike.

hits.name: The Chin (Mount Mansfield) via Sunset Ridge Trail
Mount Philo Western Loop
hits.description: This easy to moderate hike is very popular all year round. Hikers may find themselves sharing the road with mountain bikers in one season and cross country skiers the next.

hits.name: Red Rocks Park Loop Trail
hits.description:
A nice easy stroll in the woods to a couple of lovely lookouts of Lake Champlain.

Accessibility: There may not be any designated accessible spaces at the parking area on Central Avenue at the start of the trail. There are at least 4 designated and van-accessible parking spots at the parking lot marked with a waypoint. The trail surface is natural dirt or gravel, and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle except for very steep (over 12%) uphill and downhill sections from about 0.7 through 1.7 miles when going counterclockwise. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the natural and potentially uneven surface type.

The most accessible portion of the trail has its own trail page here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/vermont/red-rocks-park-trail--2

hits.name: Burnt Rock Mountain Trail
hits.description: Varying from moderate to difficult, this trail offers a shaded route up, mostly on dirt/mud with increasing granite scrambles as you near the top.  The main technical challenge is water:  it's a wet path, sometimes slippery, with at least four streams to ford.  Be ready to remove your shoes to get over the first stream.

hits.name: The Pogue and Mount Tom Trail
Nebraska Notch, Lake Mansfield Trail
hits.description: As you approach via car, there are lots of private property signs. Keep going. You will eventually see a small sign on the right directing you up a steep hill to public parking and the trailhead.

hits.name: Thundering Brook Falls
White Rocks Recreation Area Trail via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
Colchester Causeway Trail
hits.description:
A very nice and easy gravel path that is bordered on both sides by Lake Champlain.

On weekends, you will need to take a ferry across if you plan to reach South Hero Island. For ferry information, please visit https://www.localmotion.org/bike_ferry

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Colchester Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is crushed gravel or paved asphalt/cement, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Quechee Gorge Trail
hits.description:
This is a flat and scenic out-and-back walk that starts in the parking lot of Dewey’s Mills Pond and begins on a strip of land between the pond and the Ottauquechee River, ending at the Ottauquechee Dam and Waterfalls. If you choose to keep walking straight ahead beyond the dam toward the Quechee Gorge Bridge, the trail begins to climb and becomes a little more rugged.

The trail starts behind a gate just past the boat launch at the Dewey’s Mills Pond parking lot. Restrooms are available at the picnic area just beyond the dam, as are benches to rest on. Both the pond and the Ottauquechee River are full of life, so enjoy the wonderful walk!

hits.name: Laura Cowles Trail to Sunset Ridge Trail Loop
hits.description:
Up Halfway house trail and down Sunset Ridge. Trail was damp from recent rains and you are in the trees until just below the Long Trail ridge line. From there you have about 1 mile and about 400 ft of elevation to climb to the summit  which included some rock scrambles in a few places. Coming down Sunset Ridge is mainly exposed rock for the 1st two thirds of the 3 miles back to Underhill State Park camping area.

Overall, the trails are strenuous. Once on the Long Trail ridge and much of Sunset Ridge affords some beautiful views of the Lamoile and Stowe Valleys.

hits.name: Mount Olga Trail
hits.description: There is an admission fee to access this trail. For more information, please visit https://www.vtstateparks.com/fees.html

hits.name: Sherburne Pass Trail to Pico Peak
Spruce Peak via Sterling Pond Trail
Keewaydin Trail to Overlook Spur via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
Niquette Bay State Park
hits.description:
This Vermont State Park is named for Niquette Bay, the local name for an indentation along the northeastern shore of Lake Champlain's larger Malletts Bay. 4700 feet of scenic rocky and sandy shoreline along the bay comprise the park's southern boundary.

Todays 553-acre park began with an initial land purchase by the State of Vermont in 1975. It is named for Niquette Bay, the local name for an indentation along the northeastern shore of Lake Champlains larger Malletts Bay. 4700 feet of scenic rocky and sandy shoreline along the bay comprise the parks southern boundary. 

The property, much of it farmed and pastured through the 1800s, is today predominately forested. Two long ridges with summits rising to over 400 elevation run parallel along either side of a flat, sandy terrace bisecting the property. This terrace, in turn, is bisected by a brook and associated ravine. This brook, over 1000s of years, has carried away sand and silt as the ravine was carved, depositing it into Lake Champlain and forming the sandy but shallow beach along the eastern half of the parks shoreline.

Limestone cliffs form the headwall of the western of the two ridges that cut through the park. The parks trail system accesses high points along each of these ridges, from which impressive vistas overlook Malletts Bay to the south, the Green Mountain ridge line to the east, and the Lake Champlain Islands to the west. 

Management strategies at Niquette Bay work to support the vision of the park as an oasis for appreciating nature. Camping is not permitted. Day use hours are from 10 a.m. to sunset. There is no public drinking water supply, and fires are not allowed. The park trail system is comprised of three interlocking loops along which a variety of hiking combinations can occur. The complete loop around the Ledges, Muhley, and Island View trails is 3.5 miles. The shortest distance to the lakeshore is 0.6 miles, via the Allen trail. It is by design that parking is limited to 30 cars, in an area adjacent to the park office, at the entrance to the property.

Niquette Bay is pet-friendly, although proof of rabies vaccination is required and pets must remain on-leash at all times.

Pets are not permitted on the beach but are allowed to swim in the cove area.

Pet owners are expected to clean up after their pets and are responsible for any damage caused. Parties hiking with pets are limited to a maximum of four (4) animals per group.

hits.name: Owlshead Mountain Trail
hits.description: Parking is available at the New Discovery campground for $4.

hits.name: Little Rock Pond via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
Camel's Hump via Long Trail Loop
Stratton Mountain and Stratton Pond Loop
hits.description: This hike starts off with a gradual grade that has areas of mud. The hike towards the summit is a moderate grade. There is a fire tower at the top of the mountain for 360 degree views. From here descend another 3.5 miles to Stratton Pond. Here you can see loons and take a swim. The hike out on the Stratton Pond trail is flat with areas of mud and it is approximately 3.7 miles to the road, then another 0.9 miles to the parking area.

hits.name: The Long Trail
hits.description: Vermont’s Long Trail is the oldest long distance hiking trail in the United States. The trail follows the main ridge of the Green Mountains from Massachusetts-Vermont state line to the Canadian border. Novice and expert alike will enjoy the varied terrain of the trail as it passes through the heart of Vermont. For more information visit: https://www.greenmountainclub.org/the-long-trail/

hits.name: Island Line Rail Trail
hits.description:
A mix of paved and gravel paths, great for walking and biking. The Causeway is especially lovely during sunset. If you walk out enough onto the Causeway you get some great views of Vermont's mountains!

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Flynn Avenue at the start of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved or gravel, and typically at least 5 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along portions of the trail which reduces the width. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for one moderately steep (5-8%) downhill section in the first 0.1 miles when starting north. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the moderately steep section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Stowe Recreation Path
hits.description:
The Stowe Recreation Path is an internationally recognized 5.5-mile greenway, paved for nonmotorized recreation with numerous picnic and swimming areas. There is an optional quiet path near the village for joggers and walkers only.

Stowe's bike path is an all-year-round recreational trail. You can bike, hike, stroll, and ski on it, 365 days a year. The 5.3-mile paved trail starts in Stowe Village, next to the Stowe Congregational church, winds its way through the woods and meadows, and crosses the West Branch River 11 times on arched wooden bridges. Numerous shops, lodges, and restaurants are accessible from the path.

This delightful track can be enjoyed by both experienced cyclists and first-time bikers. It's also the perfect opportunity to see all that Stowe has to offer. Take a look below to see some of the beautiful scenes which can be found on this trail.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Vermont Route 100 at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

hits.name: Mount Hunger and Whiterock Mountain Loop
Mount Pisgah Via North Trail
hits.description: The North Trail starts along the eastern side of Lake Willoughby and is a shorter trip to the top than the South Trail. It's well maintained, easily followed and is notable for its views of the lake and neighboring Mount Hor.

hits.name: Overlook via Sucker Brook Hollow Trail
hits.description: Please check with the park page for more information.

hits.name: Jerusalem Trail to Mount Ellen
hits.description: This trail is fun and provides an awesome view at the ski lift. Beautiful trek through the woods with some steep sections, a little brook, and some rock scrambling.

hits.name: Hamilton Falls via Ball Mountain Dam
Stevenson Brook Trail
hits.description:
Stevenson Brook Trail starts at about 120 meters past the Park Office. From May to late October, all visitors are required to pay a day use fee of $4 for adults and $2 for kids. Pedestrians walking into the park are also required to pay the day use fee at the park office. There is parking for this trail.

Use of the park's swim beaches and boat rentals are for campers only. Waterbury Center State Park (about 20 minutes away, around the reservoir on Rte. 100 north) is available for day-use beach/boating access. 

The trail ends at the Dalley Loop Trail after approximately 2.8 miles, at which point if you turn RIGHT onto Dalley Loop, RIGHT onto the Cut-off Trail, across the stream and LEFT onto Stevenson Brook and head back toward the park road you will eventually have a 4.55 mile round-trip. In times of high water, the Cut-off Trail will require getting your feet wet. If you bypass this and return to the road on Dalley Loop it becomes a 4.89 mile round trip.

hits.name: Bald Mountain Trail
hits.description: The Bald Mountain Trail is noted for its vistas, blueberries, and wildflowers. Four vistas located at rock promontories along the trail offer panoramic views of the Green Mountain range, Otter Creek and Cold River valleys, as well as Rutland City. The hike has mostly moderate grades with a few steep descents on the West Loop and the end of the East Loop.

hits.name: Mount Abraham via Battell and Long Trail
Libby's Look Loop
hits.description: This trail can be crowded on holidays, weekends, and during leaf season traffic, please consider hiking elsewhere if there are too many people.

hits.name: Duxbury Window Viewpoint and Long Trail
Haystack Mountain via Colby M. Chester Memorial Trail
hits.description:
Generations of Pawlet families – and visitors from around the world – have climbed the steep slopes to the top of Haystack Mountain to take in the spectacular 360-degree views of Bald and Middle Mountains, the north-south forested hills and the serene Mettowee Valley. 

This preserve features a series of rounded, forested peaks in the northern Taconic Mountains, clustered in an extensive landscape of unbroken forest. Locals call Haystack, Middle and Bald Mountains the Three Sisters. Warm southern aspect and shallow soils produce drought-like conditions on the hills and promote the growth of several unusual natural communities, including dry oak woodlands and dry oak-hickory-hophornbeam forests. Turkeys, grouse and bobcats roam the rocky landscape. Peregrine falcons sometimes nest on the cliffs of Haystack. These forested hills also provide nesting habitat for neotropical migrant songbirds that rely on unfragmented forest blocks.

hits.name: Luce's Lookout
hits.description: This trail is privately owned and maintained by the landowner. Please be respectful and courteous when hiking this trail. Pack in and out trash! If the road to the trail is full of cars, please find elsewhere to hike. Do not block or turn around in driveways along the road.

hits.name: Mount Abraham and Mount Ellen Loop
hits.description:
Grab both these 4,000' peaks on a long ridge above the Sugarbush Ski Resort with an optional ski descent.

This is a fun ridge climb in winter or spring if you bring along a pair of skis for the descent.  Once you climb up the ski slopes you'll be following the Long Trail over the ridge to get both Abraham and Ellen.  You'll reach the top of Lincoln Peak first on your ascent above the highest chairlift at Sugarbush.  You'll then follow the ridge south to the bare summit of Abraham then back north a long ways across the ridge to the wooded summit of Ellen above Mad River Glen ski resort.  Don't go down these trails as you'll end up at the base of the wrong resort.  Instead, trace your steps back along the ridge where you intersect the Sugarbush trails.  Pick a trail from here, snap into your skis and head on down for a fun descent.

hits.name: Harmon Hill via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
Sunset Ledge
hits.description: Lincoln Gap Rd generally closes in the winter after the first October snowfall.

hits.name: Cady Hill Trail
hits.description: The upper and lower Florence Trail is a designated bike only section of trail by the town of Stowe.

hits.name: Echo Lake Vista Trail
hits.description: A short hike up to an overview of Okemo mountain

hits.name: Brownsville Trail
hits.description: Great hike that is well-marked.

hits.name: South Kent Pond via Appalachian Trail
Gilbert's Lookout and Owl's Head
hits.description: From Hwy 30, you will take Raptor Lane east to the end of the road to find the trailhead. You will follow the yellow and blue trails markings. You'll pass several spur trails to quarries in the first part of this hike.

hits.name: Pinnacle at Windmill Hill Loop
hits.description:
For up to date park information, please see the association page here: http://www.windmillhillpinnacle.org/

The Pinnacle at Windmill Hill is a nature area that contains numerous trails with several loop and out and back hikes. The trails are well maintained by the Windmill Hill Pinnacle Association. The summit even contains a newly renovated shelter where campers can spend the night (reservations are required).

hits.name: Belvidere Mountain
hits.description: This trail has a decent amount of parking and is not usually very crowded. The first half of the trail is well marked but can get muddy. It had great scenery including a stream that runs a lot of the way. By the time you get about 2/3rds of the way up the markers are more scarce and the path gets steeper, so save some energy and patience for this portion of the hike. Since this is one of the least travelled sections of the Long Trail, you may occasionally have the trail to yourself.

hits.name: Overlook via Five Tree Hill Trail
Rock Point Trail Loop
hits.description: Trails are located on property owned by the Episcopal Diocese but made accessible to the public through a partnership with the Lake Champlain Land Trust.  Access is free but, visitors must obtain a trail pass from the Rock Point website (www.rockpointvt.org/trails) before arriving.

hits.name: Great Cliff via Long Trail
hits.description: This short but steep trail offers great views at the top.

hits.name: Milton Town Pond Trail
hits.description: The first part of the trail is maintained and is WHEELCHAIR accessible up to the first bridge.

hits.name: Overlook Trail via West River Trail
Deer Leap Overlook and Willard Gap to Appalachian Trail Loop
hits.description: A pleasant walk in the shade. There are many rocks, some are quite slippery and a steep section.

hits.name: Devil's Gulch via Long and Babcock Trail
hits.description: To complete the loop, take the LT to the Babcock Trail intersection. From here, Devil's Gulch is an optional out and back (approximately 1 mile). Once back at the intersection, take the Babcock Trail back to the main road and return to the parking lot (approximately a quarter mile from the trail).

hits.name: Blueberry - Brook Crossing - Triborough Bridges - Teardrop Loop
Long Trail, Profanity, Long Trail, Haselton Trail Loop
Styles Peak via Long Trail
hits.description: This trail runs along Long Trail/Appalachian Trail

hits.name: Lincoln Peak via Battell and Long Trail
Deer Leap Mountain with Overlook Loop
Waterfront Park to Island Line Trail
hits.description:
This mostly paved trail heads from College Street at the Waterfront Park to the Winooski River Delta at Delta Park.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of College Street at the southeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is partially paved (asphalt, cement, wooden boardwalk and bridges with railings) or partially gravel, and is typically at least 5 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some paved portions of the trail which reduces the width. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for one steep (8-12%) uphill section at about 1.1 miles when going northwest. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steep section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Long Trail: Appalachian Gap to Mad River Warming Hut
Mount Hunger via Middlesex Trail
hits.description:
Users suggest having a 4x4 or AWD car to reach the trailhead as the road can be quite rough. 

Please beware that the last section of the trail is difficult and requires a bit of scrambling.

hits.name: Merck Forest Trail
hits.description: This is part of the larger network of dirt roads and foot trails on the Merck Farm and Forest, the Antone Road trail leads to the summit of Antone Mountain. The Antone Road trail connects at several junctions with other road and foot trails.

hits.name: Wu Ledges
hits.description: The park is open from dawn to dusk. There are no motorized vehicles allowed, fires, or overnight camping.

hits.name: Honey Hollow Trail
hits.description: During the winter, this trail is used for cross-country skiing.

hits.name: Sucker Brook Hollow and Five Tree Hill Trail
hits.description: Users have reported that the area borders private property. Please be respectful and stay along the public route.

hits.name: Bourn Pond and Stratton Pond via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
Nebraska Notch Trail and Long Trail
Mount Ellen and Abraham via Lincoln Gap
Hoot Toot and Whistle Trail
hits.description: Very little elevation gain, don't bother with the short loop near the beginning of the trail that goes down to the river. You don't see much that you didn't see walking to the trailhead. You'll go through the woods for another half mile or so, then the trail bends to follow the reservoir to a park (complete with picnic tables and port-a-potties).

hits.name: Frost Trail to Butler Lodge Trail Loop
Mobbs Valley, Mobbs Farm and Out'n Back Loop
Middlesex Trail to White Rock Trail
Summit Trail
hits.description: There is an entrance fee to all Vermont State Parks: $4 for Adults (14 and over), $2 for children (13-4) and 3 years old- infant is free. Bikes are not allowed.

hits.name: Glastenbury Mountain via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
hits.description: This is a beautiful but challenging two night backpacking trip that gets you back to your car before noon on the third day. All you have to do is park one car at the Stratton Mountain trailhead and another at the LT/AT Trailhead on Route 9. Towards the end of day two, you'll pass the trailhead on Route 9 where you car is parked and will have to backtrack around 4.5 miles the next morning.

hits.name: Preston Pond Loop to Libby's Look Loop
hits.description: This trail can be crowded on holidays, weekends, and during leaf season traffic, please consider hiking elsewhere if there are too many people.

hits.name: Slot Trail
hits.description: Spur trail from the main summit to the parking lot at the top of the Auto Road that starts at the park entrance.

hits.name: Salamander, Stegosaurus, Underdog and Dewey Wood Road
Bald Mountain
hits.description: The park is open from Memorial Day to Labor Day.

hits.name: Spruce Peak via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
The Lost Mine Trail
hits.description: The Lost Mine is a roughly 2 mile loop trail located just past the Reservoir in Chester, Vermont. The trail features a mine (the lost mine) that was in operation in the late 1800s/early 1900's which is one of only 3 known sources in the world of chesterite - a silicate mineral with a unique crystal structure - which was first discovered here back in 1977.  There's not much of a view anywhere along the trail however, the trail does eventually follow a picturesque brook.

Long Trail and Bald Mountain Loop
hits.description: There are two ways to do this loop: one is to begin at Bald Mountain’s trailhead in Bennington and following the West Ridge Trail to Glastenbury. Or to begin at the Bald Mountain Trail in Woodford. Beginning in Bennington had access to Bald Mountain’s outlook. When you begin from the Woodford side, there is not an outlook point until you reach the summit. The summit of Bald Mountain is the intersection of these two trails with the West Ridge Trail, but the views are hard to see over the treetops. The West Ridge Trail has thick overgrowth compared to the LT, but it’s still accessible.

hits.name: Hang Glider Trail
hits.description: Spur trail from the main summit to the hang glider launch deck.

hits.name: Putney Mountain Hawk Watch
hits.description:
Short, easy hike to nice views. Hawks in abundance during migration season.

A short hike that is good for families, as it's not too hard. Bird lovers will enjoy the spring and fall hawk migration seasons.  From parking take the white blazed Ridgeline Trail to the summit. It follows a well defined woods road.  Return this way or bear left on a short blue blazed trail then turn left (south) onto the yellow blazed trail and take it back to your car.

hits.name: Forest City Trail
hits.description: From the small parking lot on Camel’s Hump Road in Huntington, the trail can be used to complete a hike to Camel’s Hump summit or Mt. Ethan Allen. The Forest City Trail follows Brush Brook. Just after the long bridge crossing the brook, there is a small concrete structure on the right which once heated water for the small logging and sawmill community of Forest Mills. At 0.8 mile the trail joins the Connector Trail. Forest City Trail ends at its junction with the Long Trail. Two hundred feet from the end of the trail to the South (right), on the Long Trail, is Montclair Glen Lodge. Camel’s Hump Summit is 1.6 miles to the North (left).

hits.name: The Chin via Cliff House
hits.description:
This trail can be slippery when wet -  please use caution. 
There is a gondola on the mountain that will also bring you to the start point of this trail. The gondola costs $30.

hits.description: Leffert's Pond Trail begins at Wildcat Road and follows a fairly defined footpath going north and east for .8 miles before ending along the northern tip of Leffert's Pond.

hits.name: Raven Ridge Loop
hits.description:
This is an easy hilly trail with some rocks and roots in the path but good views at the peak ridge. There is limited parking in the parking lot (4 spots) and it can be dangerous to park on the road in this location.

If the parking lot is full, please consider hiking at another nearby trail.

hits.name: Frost, Long and Butler Lodge Trail Loop
hits.description: Start from Stevensville Road and head up the Nebraska Notch trail. Take the Clara Bow or LT to Taylor Lodge and for bonus views, climb up the little hill to the overlook in front of Taylor Lodge. Back track up the LT to the Forehead and proceed over the ridge to the Chin. Backtrack again (briefly) to the intersection w/ the Sunset Ridge Trail. Take that back down to CCC road until you hit Maple Ridge. Last climb for the day up to Maple Ridge (nice view), then back down the Frost trail back to Stevensville Road.

hits.name: Emerald Lake

hits.description: Mixed bag of hiking, mtn biking and ski trails including service road and stairs. Pick your way to the top.  Reward is a spectacular view above the tree line at the peak when not obscured by clouds.

hits.name: Black Mountain Trail

Lake Willoughby South Shore Loop
hits.description: Wonderful trail right next to Lake Willoughby. Really enjoying being up high and the nice bridges. The Cliff Trail dead ends but it’s nice. There is some footwork and rocks. Highly recommend!

hits.description: Mt Moosalamoo doesn't have an exposed summit, only a sign "here it is" but the view from Rattlesnake Cliff over Lake Dunmore is fantastic.

hits.name: Deer Mountain
hits.description: The trailhead is within the campground, which has a $4 fee to enter. When the campground closes, users reportedly park at the gate.

hits.name: Lewis Deane Loop
hits.description: Nice, easy to moderate hike, with two ways to the top that can be done as a loop. One trail, which heads south from the kiosk, is much easier with switchbacks. The main route is steeper but shorter. The view at the top is very nice, with Lake St, Catherine in the foreground and the southern Adirondacks to the west. There is a platform at the top for camping. Across Endless Brook Road is another trail system for hiking and mountain bike riding maintained by Slate Valley Trails, with some more nice views.

hits.name: Windmill Mountain
hits.description: For up to date park information, please see the association page here: http://www.windmillhillpinnacle.org/

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Clarendon Gorge to Greenwall Shelter via Long Trail
Muhley and Island View Loop Trail
Mount Mansfield Chin via Hell Brook Trail and Hasselton Trail
hits.description: Park in the Lower Barnes Lot at Stowe Mountain resort. Take the trail up to the top of the chin of Mount Mansfield. Once leaving the summit take the ridge all the way across to the toll road. There is a short walk on the toll road to get down to Hasselton trail which is well marked on the left. The Hasselton trail cuts through the woods on mostly single track and wood area with a mix of rocks.

hits.name: CCC Road to Burlington Overlook
hits.description:
This mountain trail follows the CCC Road to an opening overlooking the Champlain Valley, with distant views of Burlington, VT and Lake Champlain. 

Park at Underhill State Park and head up the Eagle's Cut Trail shortcut through the woods until joining the CCC Road, which takes you to the main trailhead for the western trails of Mt. Mansfield. From there, take a right along the gravel trail and make your way up the slight incline, passing the Halfway House trailhead, until reaching the overlook. 

This trail is a great alternative for anyone looking for a view from Mansfield but can't traverse the more difficult and steeper trails.

hits.name: Mount Hunger via Skyline trail
hits.description:
In a fashion slightly similar to some of the more 'trailless' peaks in the Adirondacks, the narrow, lightly used but marked trail winds its way along the top of the Worcester Range, sometimes dramatically. If you are looking for solitude, this is a great trail.

Most of the hike is protected by trees, but there are occasional social paths leading to delicious views of Camel's Hump, to the Sterling range and more. You can even see Lake Champlain and into the Adirondacks on a good day. Just before ending at Mount Hunger, the North summit offers better on-trail eastern views than Hunger. 

There is a bit of scrambling involved (climbing on rocks, but not rock climbing). If that is not something you adore, you might not want to bother with this one.

Starting at the lower Pinnacle parking lot or at the Pinnacle Meadows parking lot, it's steep but simple walk up to the first junction below Pinnacle. After the Hogback/Pinnacle junction, it gets slightly more tricky: 700' in well under a mile. Once atop Hogback, there is a half mile or so of treed summit area walking to the Skyline trail. Here may be the first place you encounter mud; it will not be the last.

hits.name: Styles and Peru Peak Loop
hits.description: Camping fee: $5 per person per night at the pond during the summer and fall

hits.name: Button Bay Trail
hits.description: Parking is available in Basin Harbor State Park.

hits.name: Bald Mountain Trail
hits.description:
Bennington's "White Rocks" are located within the Glastenbury Wilderness just off the Bald Mountain Trail. A great in/out hike to the White Rocks, or to the summit of Bald Mountain if you want to show a friend/family the benefits of hiking in Vermont. Trail blazes are purposely less frequent in Wilderness areas, mileages are not displayed. The vistas is marked with a rock cairn.

Great views, wildlife and dispersed camping opportunities. The southeast side of the summit is also known as Bear Wallow and is covered in wild blueberries in late summer.

The eastern approach and the connecting West Ridge Trail used to be a former portion of Long Trail and Appalachian Trail. The West Ridge Trail takes you to the AT/LT, Goddard Shelter and the summit of Glastenbury- appropriate for long-distance hikers/backpackers.

hits.name: Flatlander, Equinox Pond, and Mount Bluff Trail
Griffith Lake via Long Trail (Appalachian Trail)
hits.description: There is a shoulder to park along the road right next to the trailhead, you will see a big sign saying that Griffith lake is 6.8 miles away.  Lots of ups and downs on this trail, it isn't incredibly strenuous but a round trip of 13.6 miles is pretty lengthy.  Lots of rocks, you follow a river for most of the beginning with a decent flow for drinking water (you should still boil it).  Griffith lake is beautiful, just bring water shoes because the bottom is jagged, many sticks and rocks to step on, just be warned about the horseflies!!!! The hike back is a lot easier, quite a bit more downhill but this is a good day trip.

hits.name: Ledges Overlook Trail
hits.description:
Great hike if you want an intense but quick workout. Beautiful view of the West River and dam at the top. The trail is very well marked with yellow blazes. There is a moderate uphill climb and a great scenic overlook complete with a park bench at the top.

The park is open from Memorial Day to Labor Day.

hits.name: Black Mountain Trail
hits.description:
Black Mountain rises abruptly from the West River in Dummerston to a horseshoe ridge with a summit of 1,280 feet. The mountain originated as a mass of molten rock deep beneath the surface of the earth between 345 and 395 million years ago. Erosion has exposed the granite that forms the core of the mountain.
The lower slopes of Black Mountain are covered by hemlock and hardwoods such as sugar maple and beech. The pluton’s steep upper slopes and summit include craggy granite bedrock ledges covered by a thin layer of poor acidic soil. Here where nutrient-needy and water-loving plants can’t grow, the only pitch pine-scrub oak woodland in Vermont flourishes. Smallish pitch pines, red and white pines, oaks and red maples, lift gnarled limbs above a grassy glade cloaked in lowbush blueberry and huckleberry. Lichen-covered glacial erratics – boulders dropped by melting glaciers – are scattered about. From the top of Black Mountain there are views as far as New Hampshire’s Mount Monadnock, and into the West River and Connecticut River valleys.

hits.name: The Pogue Loop from Prosper Road
hits.description: This trail starts on Prosper Road and continues up to The Pogue. If you're looking to continue on to Mount Tom, please search AllTrails for "The Pogue and Mount Tom from Prosper Road".

hits.name: Paradise Park Loop
hits.description:
This route uses Meadow Loop, Ridge Loop, Carriage Road, Juniper Hill, Hubbard Brook, and other trails. There are more trails in this park if you'd like to extend your hike.

The trailhead shown here is for pedestrian access; parking is available a bit farther away from the trailhead. Please make sure you're parked in a secure location, as users report that cars parked too near to the trailhead have been towed.

hits.name: Missisquoi Valley Rail Trail
hits.description:
A 26 mile rail trail starting in St. Albans, Vermont, ending in Richford, Vermont.

The first third of the trail from St Albans to Sheldon passes through farm fields and forests.  From there the trail follows along the Missisquoi River through Enosburg and Berkshire to Richford.  The trail surface is uniform and hard packed, usable by all bike types.  There are several spots where the trail crosses state highway 105.  Use appropriate caution.

hits.name: Bear Hill Trail
hits.description: Trail entrance is at the back of the grassy area to the left of the fire tower once you reach the parking area.

hits.name: Burlington Bike Path
hits.description:
This trail starts at Perkins Pier Park, goes to Harrison Avenue and back.

Accessibility: There is at least one designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Maple Street at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along portions of the trail which reduces the width. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Silver Lake Campground via Silver Lake Trail
Shrewsbury Peak via Black Swamp Trail
Barnes Camp Loop
hits.description: This is a beautiful hike in Smugglers’ Notch in Stowe.  Start at Barnes Camp Hikers Visitor Center across from Stowe Ski Area and head for the Boardwalk which is physically on the Long Trail with white trail blazes, traveling south.  After viewing the magnificent views, enter the woods and at the first junction, turn right toward the picnic area, now on blue blazes.  Just before the picnic area, turn right where there is a small brook crossing.  Proceed following blue blazes to steep section that climbs about 400’ in .02 mile.  At the end of the steep section, turn right at the junction toward Barnes Camp, on the Long Trail again and following white blazes.  Gradually descend to the Barnes Camp parking lot, where your hike began.

hits.name: Beaver Meadow to Sterling Mountain, Morse Mountain, and Madonna Peak
hits.description:
Three peaks in under 10 miles! Nestled behind the Sterling ridge and Spruce, Sterling, Morse and Madonna each offer a unique take on the area. Sterling offers a staid, treed summit, Morse offers an in-your-face view of Beaver Meadow, Mansfield and everything in between. Madonna makes no bones about it, you're no longer in the backcountry; not with a ski lift and buildings to boot. 

The first two and a quarter miles just fly by though the trail is pretty wet in some places and in need of some planks. Be sure to wear waterproof shoes and to keep off the berms. After passing the first turnoff to Beaver Meadow Lodge, the trail tightens up and by the second turnoff, it changes completely. Gone is the gentle, rolling singletrack road: in its place lies a pretty chunky challenge up to the Whiteface shelter, to the tune of 1,000 vertical ft per mile. 

The Whiteface Shelter is a lean-to maintained by the Green Mountain Club (GMC) and offers commanding views to the southwest (Madonna). If you plan on starting on the trail early in the morning, this is a good place to eat. Drop packs if you like and head up the four tenths of a mile up Whiteface, but be careful. The climb is even more rocky in places than what you have encountered so far. Expect Hell Brook Trail-like levels of scrambling and wet rocks.

Sterling summit is treed and has many social paths leading to views and three to other trails. Be sure you know which way you came once you get up, it can be confusing on the way back down.

Grab your pack at the shelter and head over to Morse. There is a bit of a climb out and a false summit, but when you have a clear view of Beaver Meadow facing ESE, you have arrived. Head on over to the Chilcoot Trail intersection and then to Madonna, eight tenths of a mile after. Once you pop out onto the ski trail, you have a choice of taking that up or stay straight and you will find a ladder on the other side of the ski trail, indicating where the Long Trail goes. After summiting Madonna, turn around and come back to the Chilcoot Trail and prepare yourself for a steep, rocky descent to the plane of Beaver Meadow.

Once you've gotten yourself down here, check out or use the Beaver Meadow Lodge, also a GMC property. Hang a right over the stream and you will eventually find yourself back at the first cutoff for the Beaver Meadow Lodge and the Chilcoot trail. Turn right here and head back to the car.

It's a lovely way to spend the day and if you like, spend the weekend by staying in either the lodge or the shelter.

hits.name: Hedgehog Hill Trail
hits.description:
Use of the park's swim beaches and boat rentals are for campers only. Waterbury Center State Park (about 20 minutes away, around the reservoir on Rte. 100 north) is available for day-use beach/boating access. 

Hedgehog Hill starts on the park road by campsite 59 and ends at the Dalley Loop Trail by the Ricker Place. Round-trip using the Dalley Loop and Hedgehog Hill Trails is 2.11 miles. 

Between the 2nd weekend in May and the 3rd Monday in October, there is a day use fee to enter the park ( $4 for adults, $2 for kids). Parking is required at the dam from late October until the park opening in May.

hits.name: Birdseye Mountain
hits.description: When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

hits.name: Little Rock Pond and Green Mountain Loop
hits.description: The hike traverses the summit of Green Mountain a ridgeline revealing views of the surrounding mountains and Little Rock Pond.

hits.name: Camel Hump via Monroe, Alpine, Long and Dean Trail
Japanese Garden, South Meadow and Falls Trail
hits.description: You can access this trail through the Taconic Ramble State Park entrance which branches south off of St. John Road.  A beautiful trail that goes through all types of terrain, through meadows, woods and by waterfalls. Take the trail to the Japanese Garden, then to south Meadow, and to Falls trail to the Wire bridge and finally back out the same trail to where you started.

When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. hits.name: Mendon Peak
hits.description:
If you are looking at the Bucklin Traillhead on Wheelerville Road in Mendon / Killington, Vermont, there is a  gate located just to the right; this is the start of the hike to Mendon Peak.

Hike on the old logging road past the gate for roughly 1 mile where you will find yourself at a fork. (You will pass a house on your left at the [roughly] 0.65 mile mark). At this fork go left. In roughly 0.25 miles, fork left again. Then shortly after (roughly 0.10 miles) fork right. You will fork right again in roughly 0.70 miles. In roughly 0.20 miles go left, then shortly after (roughly 0.10 miles) go right. 

In roughly 0.10 miles you will cross a river. Shortly after (roughly 0.10 miles) you will fork right. You will cross the river again at roughly 0.30 miles. You will see a cairn in roughly 0.25 miles, and the main logging road you are on turns left. In roughly 0.20 miles, there is another cairn that marks the beginning of the bushwhack. Turn right into the woods to begin your bushwhack. There is a herd path the entire way up, but you may lose it, and pick it back up again on and off. The herd path closer to the summit is obvious.

hits.name: Bourne Pond via Branch Pond Trail
Bluff Mountain Community Trail
hits.description: Took Bluff Mtn Community Trail to the "Overlook" via the Lookout Trail. Contined on over Bluff Mtn Summit to "North View" and returned to parking lot via a loop trail east of the Overlook. Moderate hike, short steep section on the way up to the overlook has metal rungs fastened into the rock.

hits.name: North Springfield Reservoir Trail
hits.description: To complete the full loop you must cross back over the river just before the Power Dam, during autumn and winter this is pretty simple as it will be very shallow or completely frozen over however, in the spring and early summer the water will be much higher and faster obviously making crossing risky

hits.description: You can access this trail through the Taconic Ramble State Park entrance which branches south off of St. John Road.

hits.name: Breadloaf and Battell Mountains via Long Trail
Aldis Hill Loop
hits.description: Well used trails with a map at the beginning though not marked with blazes. Also not great parking at start of trail.

hits.name: Hogback Mountain
hits.description: You will follow the orange and white blazes on this route. The blazes can be hard to follow in the middle of the trail so you may want to download the offline map. There are also signs that point towards the summit.

hits.name: Lower Prince, Middle Prince, Klondike and Gettysburg Quarries
Mt. Philo Access Road
hits.description: There is an entrance fee to all Vermont State Parks: $4 for Adults (14 and over), $2 for children (13-4) and 3 years old- infant is free.

hits.name: Equinox Mountain via Skyline Drive
hits.description: This route is a scenic drive on a paved road.

hits.name: Teardrop Trail
hits.description:
It is advised not to use this trail during spring through fall as is not maintained or marked. It is very easy to get lost on this trail if you don't know where you're going. 

This is a ski trail for winter use only, not hiking.

hits.name: White Rock Mountain via Middlesex Trail
hits.description:
White Rock Mountain has a wide open rocky summit offering sweeping 360-degree views of the surrounding area.

The Middlesex Trail can be steep in spots with rocky sections and exposed roots that are very slippery when wet. Some log ladders and stairs are in place to help in some spots. Shoes with good traction are necessary.

hits.name: Camels Hump, Ethan Allen, Ira Allen via Long Trail
Stratton Mountain Firetower Trail
hits.description:
This trail is accessed from the top of the Summit Gondola. The gondola begins operating Memorial Day Weekend for the summer season. The trail can be accessed by hiking to the top of the chairlift in the off season.

For more information on gondola use please visit: https://www.stratton.com/the-mountain/discover-stratton-summer

hits.name: Chandler Ridge Trail and Leicester Hollow Trail Loop
Barr Hill Trail
hits.description: Barr Hill is the highest point in Greensboro. From the open field at the trailhead there is a stunning, nearly panoramic view that sweeps from Spruce and Signal Mountains at Groton State Park to the southern Green Mountains, Woodbury Mountain, Camel’s Hump, Elmore Mountain and Mount Mansfield. The trail traverses fern glades and a ledge outcropping once ground down by glaciers and passes through dark, coniferous woods where you’ll find beds of sphagnum moss so thick it’s tempting to stretch out and take a nap. Barr Hill is also an excellent place for bird watching. If you have binoculars you may see hawks and northern ravens from the trail lookouts.

hits.name: Nichols Ledge
hits.description: A very short hike to a beautiful viewpoint!

hits.name: Dog Head Falls via Lamoille Valley Rail Trail
Averill Mountain
hits.description: Beautiful ledge view south over Great Averill Lake.

hits.name: West River Trail - Lower Section
hits.description:
Beautiful views of the West River and many birds. The first portion of the trail is along the roadway then it turns to a natural riverside pathway.

Accessibility: There are at least 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Putney Road at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, gravel, or natural (dirt/grass/rock) and typically ranges from at least 3 to 6 feet wide.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.8 miles heading northwest. This section is mainly along the roadway. Wearing a helmet, bright clothing, and using lights or flags is always recommended when sharing space with motor vehicles. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections after about 0.8 miles when going north/westbound. 

Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections past about 0.8 miles or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved, uneven, and potentially soft sections. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Red Rocks Park Trail
hits.description:
A nice stroll in the woods to a couple of lovely lookouts of Lake Champlain. The difficulty rating is based on what the experience may be like for a manual wheelchair or stroller user since there are moderately steep sections up to 8% grade and the surface can be slippery since not paved.

Accessibility: This is the most friendly trail in the park for trail goers using a wheelchair, mobility equipment, or a stroller. The trail surface is dirt or gravel and it is typically at least four feet wide. It is typically mostly gentle (5% grade or less) but there are a couple of moderately steep (5% to 8% grade) sections between about the 0.4 and 0.7 mile marks where assistance may be needed. Depending on recent and current weather and trail conditions this trail may be to slippery or soft to safely navigate with mobility equipment, or all-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed.

It is unclear if there is designated wheelchair-accessible parking at the start of the trail on a firm and level surface.

hits.name: Hazen Trail
hits.description: A significant portion of this trail is located on Museum property. Visitors need to pay Museum admission to walk this trail. For more information please visit: https://www.montshire.org/

hits.name: Camel's Hump via Long Trail South
Stevensville Long Trail Loop
hits.description:
Drive to the end of Stevensville Road in Underhill Center and park at the trailhead. Parking is limited and not allowed in the narrow road to prevent traffic congestion in potential emergency situations.

Take the Butler Lodge Trail to Butler Lodge, then take Wallace Cutoff to connect to the Long Trail. Take Long Trail south to the Nebraska Notch Trail and return to the Stevensville Road Trailhead.

The trail is moderate from the starting point to the Twinbrooks tenting area, then turns into an easy hike.

hits.name: Stratton Mt to Mike’s Way
hits.description: Trail starts in Stratton Village to Gondola lift, take Lower Wanderer to covered bridge, bear left to bottom of Snowbowl lift, make a right uphill on Drifter Link to West/East Meadow. You will arrive at a service road and continue up it to Mike’s Way.

hits.name: Mount Ellen and Mount Abraham via Jerusalem Trail
Mt Philo Trail Loop
hits.description: There is an entrance fee to all Vermont State Parks: $4 for Adults (14 and over), $2 for children (13-4) and 3 years old- infant is free. Bikes are not allowed.

hits.name: Goddard Shelter via West Ridge Trail
hits.description:
This trail begins in Bennington and takes you over Bald Mountain (AKA: East Mountain) and on to Glastenbury Mountain.  The distance for this hike is about 13.2 miles.  You will need to spend the night at Glastenbury Mountain, unless you have the energy to hike out 14.4 miles to Route 9 in Woodford.

You can also access the trail via Bear Wallow Trail in Woodford, VT.

hits.name: Mount Peg Foot and Bridle Trails
Mt. Abraham and Mt. Ellen via Battell Trail
Pew Forest Trail
hits.description:
The Equinox Highlands, namely Mount Equinox (3,816 feet) and Mother Myrick Mountain (3,361 feet), are part of the northernmost sweep of the Taconic Mountains, and are considered one of the most important natural areas in the state. The largest rich northern hardwood forest in New England—over 2,000 acres—is located on Mount Equinox, and there is a smaller stand of this natural community type on Mother Myrick Mountain.

The deep humus soil that slowly slips down steep slopes into coves and pockets on these mountains provides a perfect environment for fast-growing hardwood trees and a wide array of spring ephemerals and other wildflowers—bloodroot, hepatica, Dutchman’s breeches, trillium, wild leek, wild ginger, squirrel corn and toothwort.

hits.name: Jerusalem Trail to Stark's Nest at Mount Stark Summit
The Pogue and Mount Tom from Prosper Road
hits.description:
You must use snowshoes or xc skis on this trail in the winter when it's groomed for xc skiing. You are also required to buy a trail pass from the xc ski center.

This trail starts at Prosper Road and continues up past the Pogue towards Mount Tom. This is a popular snowshoeing and cross-country skiing area.

If you're looking for the trail solely to the Pogue, please search AllTrails for "The Pogue Loop from Prosper Road".

hits.name: Stowe Pinnacle to Hunger via Skyline Trail
hits.description: This trail can also be done as an out-and-back!

hits.name: Shelburne Pond
hits.description:
Located just 10 miles from the metropolis of Burlington, Shelburne Pond has retained its wild and rich character despite the pressures of development. 

There are over 400 acres of swamps, marshes, and rich woods associated with the pond. These habitats support several unusual plants—especially ephemeral spring wildflowers—and birds.

The pond also serves as an important educational resource for the University of Vermont. Now largely owned and maintained by the University of Vermont (UVM), the H. Laurence Achilles Natural Area at Shelburne Pond — named for the philanthropist who supported the Conservancy's earliest acquisitions there — is a place where conservation, recreation, and research peacefully coexist.

Over 30 years in the making, the natural area at Shelburne Pond is one of the oldest and longest-running protection projects of the Vermont chapter and a successful collaboration between the Conservancy and UVM.

hits.name: Delaware & Hudson Rail Trail
hits.description:
This gravel rail-trail goes from Castleton through Poultney. Users suggest using a hybrid bike with a wider tire for this trail. 

Accessibility: There are at least 6 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Alumni Drive at about 0.5 miles at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Depot Street in Poultney at about 7.7 miles at the south end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. These parking lots have been marked with waypoints. 

The trail surface is packed gravel with some grass or bumps, and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less), except for steep (8-12%) and very steep (over 12%) sections at about 2.0 miles and 8.1 miles uphill when going south. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.

hits.name: Rum Runners Hideaway via Meadowlark Trail
The Long Trail
hits.description:
The Long Trail runs the entire distance of the state of Vermont. It is the oldest long distance trail in the US and runs along the main ridge of the Green Mountains and provides many backcountry campsites throughout. It can be hiked point to point as a long distance backpacking trip or segmented as shorter day hikes or weekend overnight trips. The entirety of the trail is marked by 2x6 inch white blazes, intersections will have signage and double blazes will signify important turns.

More information can be found here: https://www.greenmountainclub.org/the-long-trail/

hits.name: Chickering Bog Nature Trail
hits.description:
Just 15 minutes from Vermont's state capitol of Montpelier, this wide-open peatland, circled by dark tamarack, spruce and fir forest, feels as if it is a world away. 

Chickering Bog began to form when glaciers receded from Vermont over 10,000 years ago and left behind a bedrock basin that filled with water. Chickering Bog is actually misnamed; this so-called bog is really a fen. Water enters bogs solely through rainwater, while fens like Chickering Bog are also fed by calcium-rich groundwater and springs.

A one mile trail and boardwalk passes through a second growth mixed conifer/broadleaved forest before reaching the fen boardwalk which allows visitors to get close to the myriad of fen plants such as blue flag iris and showy lady's slipper orchids, as well as to wildlife. Bullfrogs, pickerel frogs, northern leopard frogs and wood frogs all strike up their choruses in season. Wood ducks, barred owls, pileated woodpeckers, swamp sparrows and other birds are found here. 

In winter, the tracks of mammals ranging from fishers to white-tailed deer and snowshoe hares crisscross the fen's frozen surface. With the help of the Vermont Youth Conservation Corps the boardwalk was reconstructed in 2006 to provide an unobstructed view of the fen and wetland plants by allowing visitors to walk out over the wetland without disturbing it.

hits.name: Glenn Falls Trail
hits.description: Trailhead is 100 feet up the road from the car park just across from the tennis court. First part of the trail is an easy stroll through the forest. After the main falls the path becomes narrow with unsure footing and steep drop offs.

hits.name: Hilltop Loop
hits.description: This is a serene trail through woods and along a beautiful brook.

hits.name: Montshire’s Ridge and Hazen Trail
hits.description: A significant portion of this trail is located on Museum property. Visitors need to pay Museum admission to walk this trail. For more information please visit: https://www.montshire.org/

hits.name: Hapgood Pond Loop
hits.description: Great beginner trail around Hapgood Lake. Pretty easy, minimal elevation change. Can be done in flip flops. Beautiful views of the lake and streams.

hits.name: Chipman Hill Loop
hits.description: Spring Street Connector, TAM/Sidewinder, Super Seven, Reehab and East-West Connector.

hits.name: Butternut Hill Trail
hits.description: Butternut Hill Natural Area was conserved in partnership with the Lake Champlain Land Trust and consists of approximately 77 acres of a mix of wetlands, uplands, two small agricultural fields, and over 500ft of undeveloped Lake Champlain shoreline. The two wetlands are both long, narrow branches of Lakeside Floodplain Forest divided by a low, forested ridge with a beech forest containing impressively large trees and a small patch of red cedar woodland along the rocky bluff at the lake shore.

hits.name: Gile Mountain via Blue Ribbon Trail
Irish Hill via Darling Road Trail
Smugglers Notch and Sterling Mountain via Long Trail
Mount Roosevelt and Mount Wilson via Clark Brook Trail
Lake Mansfield Trail to Long Trail
hits.description: This trail begins at the Lake Mansfield Trout Club, goes up the Nebraska Notch Trail, then hits the long trail by Taylor Lodge. The trail ends at the Smuggler’s Notch Picnic Area on VT 108.

hits.name: White Rocks via the Northwest Slide Loop
hits.description: The trail starts from the White Rocks National Recreation Area Parking Lot and is fairly easy walking. Eventually, you reach a panoramic viewpoint that looks directly at the slide. From here, you have a short descent to the base of the slide. The slide ascent starts of with a lot of route finding, since you are mostly bouldering until you get above the trees, which marks about the halfway point. From here on out, expect some tough footing on scree and some amazing views of Wallingford and the surrounding area. At about the 3/4 mark up the slide, grade gets steeper to summit, which has some breathtaking views of the green mountains and beyond.

hits.name: Ranch Valley to Burt Trail and Kimmer’s Trail
hits.description: Off line map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked and/or that there may be poor cell reception in this area. If you want to do a shorter hike you can drive up further past the trailhead until the end of the road.

hits.name: Mosley Hill via Appalachian Trail Loop
Appalachian Trail: State Route 140 to Clarendon Shelter via Long Trail
Appalachian Trail: Kent Pond to Green Gate Road

hits.name: Bear Run, Upper Crossover, Lower Crossover and Abenaki Trail
Mount Worcester via Skyline Trail
hits.description:
This 11.5 mile round trip offers up stunning views, solitude and 6000' of elevation gain, though interestingly, the summit in question is about 300' lower in elevation than one of the trail junctions. Start from the Pinnacle Meadow parking lot. After picking up 1,000 feet in a mile heading over Hogback to the Skyline trail junction - the highest point of the trip at 3573' - the trail morphs into slightly disturbed ground cover. Painted trilliums and other plants are growing in the middle of this non-compacted trail surface. Exposed leaf litter and duff are the only indications of where the trail goes apart from blue blazes. 

The southern half of the Skyline Trail has its share of rocky changes in elevation, but the admittedly smoother path of this northern half packs a bit more punch.

On to the moose element: scat and footprints lined the trail solidly between Worcester and the middle peak. The trail is often wet in places and though the ridge line is not a wetland, it is pretty soft in many places off trail.

Clambering up the false summit offers a decent view of the surrounding topography to the southwest including West Hill, which Google Earth mistakenly throws in the path of the trail. (it is actually the little bump to the southeast of the middle peak). You will find yourself on the summit in 20 minutes.

hits.name: Hannum Hill, Dine Trailhead, and Parkman Wood Road Trailhead Loop
hits.description:
This is a very pleasant 4 mile loop hike starting at 133 Parkman Wood Road. Take Conte Trail (red, 0.45mi), turn North on Hannum Trail (yellow, for 0.2 mi). Continue onto Dine Trail (White, 1.5 mi) until the trailhead. Turn left onto Holland Hill Road (0.2 mi). At the small parking area on the left, take Hannum Trail at trailhead (yellow, 1.2 mi). After 0.2 miles, you have the option to take High Road Trail (blue, 0.5 mi) as it parallels and meets back up with Hannum. 

Continued on Hannum. This section of Hannum does not appear to be heavily used. Be sure to always be looking ahead to the next trail marker, as the path is not always obvious. After 1.2 miles, take the red trail (Conte Trail) at the sign for ‘Parkman Wood Rd, 0.45 mi.’, back to where you started. 

Some small sections of the trail can be muddy/wet in early May, and hiking poles, though not necessary for this hike, help negotiate to hop from/to rocks and logs.

hits.name: St. Johnsbury Red and Yellow Trail
Gilbrook Loop
hits.description:
This loop starts from the Winooski Public Works Building and heads around the Gilbrook Natural Area.

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are designated accessible spaces in the partially paved parking lot off of Gilbrook Road at the west end of the trail. There is at least one spot with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is natural and typically at least 3 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type throughout.

hits.name: Trail Around Middlebury: Beldens to Middlenury
Kingsland Bay Trail
hits.description: This park is open between Memorial Day weekend and Columbus Day. Pets are NOT allowed in the park.

hits.name: Randolph Reservoir Loop
hits.description: This trail is one of several trails in the Randolph area. They are under the authority of R.A.S.T.A. (Rochester/Randolph Area Sports Trail Alliance). There are several other mountain biking trails in this area.

hits.name: The Snicket
hits.description:
The Snicket is a .42 mile moderately trafficked out and back trail located near Manchester, Vermont that is easy.

You can park at West Union Street Lot (second lot, first lot says "additional parking".  Take the Red Gate Trail .5 miles to Snicket, Yellow and black blaze on the left after passing Flatlanders Pass.  Snicket crosses back over Red Gate Trail towards the end, and ends connecting to Trillium (Green) and Mt. Bluff Trail (white).

hits.name: Eshqua Bog Natural Area
hits.description:
Eshqua Bog is a botanical wonderland of cold-climate holdovers--small pockets of bog plant species and a two acre fen--from the post-glacial era 10,000 years ago. This preserve contains a diverse array of bog and fen plants: labrador tea, cotton grass, pitcher plants, showy lady's slippers, larches and buckbean. 

In springtime, this tiny 40.8-acre preserve, circling the mere speck of an 8-acre bog, bursts forth with color, texture, shapes and scents. Most stunning are the wild orchids. Hundreds of showy lady’s slippers, along with lesser populations of small yellow lady’s slippers, dot the wetland. The somewhat more common pink lady’s slipper abounds here too, along with the northern green orchids and white bog orchids.

hits.name: Wheeler Loop and South Burlington Community Gardens
hits.description:
Depending on weather and trail conditions this route may be muddy and slippery. Use caution.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Swift Street at the northwest end of the trail. The nearest designated accessible parking is marked with a waypoint to the north of Swift Street by the baseball diamonds. 6 of the spots there are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is natural and typically at least 3 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is from 0.0 through 0.6 miles or 1.3 through 1.7 miles when heading counterclockwise. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to very steep (over 5%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.2, 0.6 through 1.2, and 1.6 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved, uneven, narrow, and potentially soft surface type.

hits.name: Willard Gap and Deer Leap Mountain via Appalachian Trail
Belvidere Mountain via Frank Post Trail, Long Trail, and Forester Trail
hits.description:
As of August 9th, 2020, the trail is inaccessible due to a washed out road.

Moderate hike via Frank Post Trail (Blue Blazes), Long Trail (White Blazes), and Forester Trail

This hike takes you to a 50-foot fire tower where you will have views of the Green Mountains, the Cold Hollow Mountains, and, if you get good weather you may be able to see Mount Washington as well. Since this is one of the least travelled sections of the Long Trail, you may have the trail to yourself.

hits.name: Primitive Trail to West Lake
hits.description: Trail is marked by blue markers, easy to follow. Medium difficulty (some steep parts) but very nice. No immediate access to lake Raponda when you arrive

hits.name: Cape Lookoff Mountain
hits.description: This mountain also passes The Great Cliff, and Mount Horrid.

hits.name: The Pinnacle via J. Latham Trail
hits.description: This trail is fairly well marked with the exception of a couple of turns that aren't very clear at first.  There aren't many steep climbs or rock scrambles. There is parking space at the trailhead, but the road getting to it is poorly maintained.

hits.name: Little Black Mountain
hits.description:
Short trail that is wide and gentle leading to a top with rock slabs, wild blueberry bushes, and views of NH and the West River.

When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

hits.name: Moose Brook to W.B. Brown to Pine Drop to Simonds Way Loop

Cross Vermont Rail Trail
hits.description:
A long-distance trail along the Wells River Valley.
For more information on the Cross Vermont Trail Association, please visit: https://www.crossvermont.org/index.php

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the unpaved parking area off of State Forest Road 232 at the northwest end of the trail. There is at least 1 designated and van-accessible parking spot with an access aisle in Gronton off of Main Street, marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is paved, gravel, or dirt and typically at least 6 feet wide.  Some extended portions of this trail are alongside highway 302, Brown Drive, and Little Italy Road. The estimated grade is mostly gentle except for steep (8-12%) sections at about 6.9, 13.2, and 14.1-mile marks when going southbound. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved and potentially soft or uneven areas.

hits.name: Missisquoi Jeep Trail
hits.description: This route is only open from August to April.

hits.name: Killington (Extended) Loop
hits.description: This is a more rigorous and lengthened approach to Killington. It takes you deep into the woods and up to the Long Trail in order to ascend to Killington Peak. The trail is heavily overgrown in most areas but offers a fresh alternative to the straight ascent hikers normally take. Take your time and enjoy the incredible silence and alternative route to the top of the Beast of the East.
