hits.name: Inner Peace, River Run, Beaver Pond Loop
Bryant Cabin to Birch Loop
hits.description:
Starting at the base of Bolton Valley ski area, hike over to the Nordic skiing section to the left (north). The Bryant trail in made up of small chunks of pink granite (which is probable needed for snowcat travel in the winter) leads up into a notch west of the ridge of Bolton mountain. The Bryant cabin is about a mile up this trail. You will pass many Nordic trails such as World Cup, Cliff Hanger, Possum and Coyote. 

About 1/3 mile up you will see Birch loop which takes you across to the Bolton-Trapp trail. Coming down this trail back to Bryant cabin you come upon what looks like a deck. 

Make your way back downhill through some open meadows and you are back at Bryant cabin. Hike back to the base and you wish you did more. 

So many other loops in these woods to explore. Check out the Nordic ski trail maps from Bolton Valley.

hits.name: Harrington’s View
hits.description: Beginning at 2844 Notch Rd, where Duck Brook Trail crosses the road, proceed steeply uphill for about a mile to intersection with Long Trail. Turn left and proceed northward along gentler slope about 2.4 miles where sign to Harrington View designates trail to the view about 50 yards further: Mt. Mansfield to the north and Bolton Valley ski area to the south.  Return to start along same route.

hits.name: Serenity, Locomotion, Vast, #6 and Westside Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Barre Town Forest – Millstone Trails Association

hits.name: Big Jay Peak
hits.description: Once you reach Jay Peak there is no trail to Big Jay Peak. You will have to hike along a herd path. Use caution, and turn back if you do not possess the navigational skills or gear to make the trek to Big Jay.

hits.name: Tucker Mountain
hits.description:
This is a beautiful hike leading up to an amazing view at the summit. There is trail parking on Tucker Mountain Rd, just past the yellow house about 300 feet up the road. When hiking the trail, you’ll come to a 4 road intersection, take the High Meadows Trail on the left to get to the summit. The path on the right that slopes up leads to a yummy, overflowing, wild raspberry patch that is ripe in early to mid-July!

On the way to the summit, you’ll see beautiful meadows and pastures, filled with wild flowers.

You’ll see some historical sites on the hike up. On the right side of the trail of Tucker Mountain Rd you’ll see the Red House that was built in the 1800’s. It’s a bit overgrown to be able to see it in summer, but in winter you’re able to see it!

hits.name: North Branch and Sparrow Arm Loop
Kelly Camp Trail
hits.description: This forest road is a little less remote than other roadside camping opportunities. Off Route 9, it dead-ends a couple miles in. Campsites are found unevenly spaced along the way.

hits.name: Long Trail: VT-118 to Corliss Camp
hits.description: Can make this hike 0.3 miles longer if you go on a few side paths (one leading to a shelter, and the other leading to a view of Ritterbush pond). This hike goes over four peaks - Bowen Mountain North, Bowen Mountain South, Butternut Mountain, and Laraway Mountain. This hike also goes through the Devil’s Gulch.

Campsites must be paddled to via the boat launch.  More information about camping accessibility can be found on the Vermont State Parks website: https://vtstateparks.com/grriver.html

hits.name: Slayton Pasture Cabin via Sugar Road, Yerrick's Yodel, and Cabin Trail
hits.description:
These trails are on the property of the Trapp Family Lodge in Stowe, VT. For more information about the property please visit: https://www.trappfamily.com/

There is a daily or seasonal use pass available for sale to access the property.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: North from Tigertown Road
West Pawlett-Rupert VT Rail Trail
hits.description: The West Pawlet to Rupert, Delaware and Hudson Rail Trail has beautiful country charm with streams, bridges, farm fields, hills, and mountain views. Bicyclists may choose to follow the recorded loop to Chet Clark Road, Rupert Road, and back down Pawlett Mountain Road for outstanding views of Haystack and surrounding mountains. This mapped biking section OFF the rail trail is difficult to strenuous, with the top section of the Chet Clark Road unmaintained and rocky. For a less challenging bike ride, remain on the rail trail for a moderate incline to Rupert. The return to West Pawlet is noticeably easier. There are parking areas 10 miles apart, at each end of the 20 mile round trip. At the Rupert end of the trail, which is past the parking area, there is a brook to sit at and enjoy lunch or a break. There are also several benches on the trail to relax and rest. The trail was resurfaced with crushed stone in 2020. Be cautious of the wildlife holes in some areas of the trail.

hits.name: LaPlatte River Marsh Trail
hits.description:
Every acre counts in this river shore natural area in Shelburne--an oasis of nature in an otherwise fragmented landscape. An important habitat for migratory waterfowl, this marsh complex is located at the end of the LaPlatte, a river that extends 16 miles from Lake Iroquois to Lake Champlain and drains 34,137 acres of Champlain lowlands. 

Nearly 150 acres in size, the marshes and floodplain forests are regularly flooded when the lake level rises and are inhabited by plant species that can endure these wet conditions. This ecosystem is essential to helping filter and clean the water that empties into the Lake and is part of the nature based solutions for water quality progress in Lake Champlain.

This preserve is a haven to sixty species of birds, twenty mammals including otter, mink and muskrat, and fifty species of reptiles, amphibians and fish. On the trail, you can expect to be surprised by ducks, kingfishers, or an occasional osprey and paddlers often spy blue herons.

hits.name: Deerfield Creek East Branch from Somerset Road
Newark Pond Trail
hits.description: The Newark Pond Natural Area includes a small island with nesting state threatened common loons and 2,410 feet of wild and protected shoreline. The Vermont Center for Ecostudies monitors loon activity on the pond. Common loons can be seen from the Conservancy’s trail along the shore of Newark Pond. Please stay at least 200 feet from loon nests May 15 to August 15.

hits.name: Upper Trail and Beaver Pond Trail Loop
Hellbrook to Haselton
hits.description: Hellbrook is as hard as it gets. Wet, rocky, and technically difficult, steep. Up to the Adam’s apple is difficult. Long Trail up to the chin is difficult at best, but so worth it. Long Trail to the rest of the face is a pleasant hike. Long Trail after the forehead is difficult. The forehead bypass and south link are similar to Hellbrook. Haselton to the end is moderate, not a lot to see after the forehead.

hits.name: Short Aldrich Trail and Park Street Spur
Bermie Sanders Loop
hits.description: For more information, please see the park's Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/FriendsofCrickethilltrails/

hits.name: Warren and Ruth Beeken Rivershore Trail
Long Trail: Highway 4 to South Park Road
Mount Horrid via the Long Trail
Hazen’s Notch to Haystack Mountain via Long Trail
Mount Ira and Mount Ethan Allen Peaks Trail
Wallingford Pond to Little Rock Pond
hits.description: Hike starts at Wallingford Pond Parking lot. It then joins Long Trail/Appalachian Trail to reach Little Rock Pond. Moderate difficulty. With a few streams to cross (on bridges) and beautiful scenery. It goes up and down but not strenuous at all.

hits.name: Little John, Capital, TNT and Locomotion Loop
hits.area_name: Barre Town Forest – Millstone Trails Association

hits.name: Worcester Range Ridge (White Rock to Mt. Worcester)
hits.description:
Fall hike. Wet trails. Hike up to White’s is gradual/moderate and a good little hike. Ladders and stairs near top. Well marked trail.

Connection to Hunger mountain is quick but wet.  Dense woods but well marked trail.

From Hunger to hogback/Worcester fork is up/down and manageable. Very wet. No views as woods are dense. Just gotta truck along.

From fork to Worcester Mtn it is very up/down, very remote feeling. Trail is poorly marked. Not nearly as well kept. Potential for wildlife viewing is HIGH: lots of moose and bear poop along trail.

Top of Worcester Mountain has a cool vantage point of the range and the green mountains. Not a large peak. The way down is steep granite, not anything scary though. 

From peak to Worcester trail head, you follow a brook for a while (more wet trail but with shifting rocks) and once you enter the mixed/deciduous woods area, the trail levels out for the majority of the way and makes for a gradual descent. Lovely woods with a wide path towards the bottom. Not well marked at all with a couple forks near the trail head so be aware.

Long day but good way to experience the range if you’re comfortable with its remoteness!

hits.name: Black Bear, Haul, Stormin Norman Loop
hits.description: This route is primarily used for mountain biking.

hits.name: Long Trail: South from Brandon Gap
White River Ledges Trail
hits.description:
Nestled in the Central Vermont Piedmont region on the shores of the White River is a protected area containing several natural communities that are representative of the region, including floodplain forest and northern hardwood forest. 

A walk through the hills here can yield surprising views of the valley landscape and of unexpected species like the distinctive rattlesnake plantain orchid. A hydrological phenomenon known as ice shear creates ideal conditions for several rare plants along this portion of the White River. In winter, ice sheets build up on the stream. In spring, the ice breaks up and jagged chunks float downstream, scouring the shore, and removing woody shrubs and tree seedlings. Only hardy herbaceous plants and mosses survive this annual scouring.

hits.name: Long Trail North
hits.description:
This part of the Long Trail goes through two fields, along Duxbury road, and over a suspension bridge. Some of the trail shares the road with vehicles, so using reflective materials, lights, or flagging is recommended for safety. You can park at either end of the trail. 

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Theodore Roosevelt Highway at the northwest end of the trail.  There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is a natural surface (dirt, leaves, rocks) or paved asphalt road. It is typically at least 5 feet wide. There are metal bollards at the entrance of the trail which reduces the width temporarily. There is an offset gate across the trail at the start and the estimated width to go around it is 3 feet. There is a railroad crossing at the start of the trail as well. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 0.7 miles when going southeast. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.

hits.name: Dalley Loop Trail
hits.description:
The trail follows an old logging road through the forest, over small brooks, and past the remains of several old homesteads.

The trail is named after Dan Dalley, a local Civil War Veteran who fought in 16 battles. He bought the property in 1878 and lived here until he died in 1925. At one point about 50 families lived in the area where the park is today.

hits.name: Spear Street and I-189 Recreation Path
hits.description:
This paved trail parallels Spear Street and connects the Gucciardi Recreation Center with Farrell Street.

Accessibility: There are at least 8 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Davis Road at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved with mostly asphalt and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) downhill sections at about 0.3 and 2.1 miles when going south/westbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: South Glastenbury Charcoal Kilns
hits.description: Start at the Woodford Town Offices as there are no places to park along Harbor Road that you can be sure your vehicle won't be towed. Follow harbor road to the end and you will find the tail going straight ahead. This trail is an easy hike until you veer right at "The Forks". You will cross several bridges and several gates on your way to "The Forks". At just over 4 miles you will come to "The Forks" shortly after you go by the camp. At "The Forks", do not cross the bridge. Stay on the near side and follow the trail to the right. (Currently has a large dead fall blocking it.) (From here, you will be in overgrown rail bed, washed out sections and if you want to see the 2 sets or kilns you will be climbing over rocks uphill.) Just after going under the tree watch uphill to the right for a foundation. This will be the nearer set of 3 charcoal kilns. Continue up the trail (The old rail bed) through the washed out section with another stream joining from the right. You will find, possibly, the landing area for the next set of 3 larger charcoal kilns uphill to the right. Possible that this was not a landing, but the Club House, however the rail partly into the foundation make me think not. The hotel, club house and school all were in this general area but nearly impossible to locate foundations that you can be sure of.

hits.name: Long Trail: Mad Tom Gap to Bromely Mountain
Madonna Peak via Sterling Pond Trail
hits.description: From the Sterling Pond Trailhead, follow the Sterling Pond Trail for about a mile before the trail reaches the pond. From the pond, continue a little over a mile to the top of Madonna Peak. A lift for Smuggler's Notch Ski Resort runs to the top of the mountain and there are views looking down the ski slopes.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: West Hartford to Thistle Hill
Colchester Bike Path
hits.description:
This paved trail is multi-use and starts from Hollow Creek Drive heading to Bayview Drive and back.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces at the northeast end of the trail. The nearest designated accessible parking is off of Creek Farm Road, marked with a waypoint. All of the spots there are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved with mostly asphalt (with railings at bridges), and typically at least 6 feet wide. There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.0, 0.6, and 1.3 miles when going southbound. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Peak A View
hits.description: This trail starts at the house Edson Hill property. Starting the hike here may require that you're a guest of the resort, or pay for a pass.

hits.name: North Branch Trail to Voter's Brook Overlook
Lake Raponda Trail
hits.description: Starts in lake Raponda parking lot off lake Raponda road. You follow the trail but it splits a few times so you have different options. Well marked.

hits.name: Trail around Middlebury and Jackson Trail Loop
Lye Brook to Branch Pond Loop
hits.description: Please note that this trail is overgrown and bushwhacking is involved.

hits.name: Calkins and Blue Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Calkins Trail runs alongside the Winooksi River in a floodplain area home to many farms. This area is great for bird watching. The trail can be muddy in the springtime and buggy since it is near plenty of water. Bug spray is nice to bring along in the spring and summer.

Follow the trail to McKenzie Park and loop around on the Blue Trail before heading back.

hits.name: Newport Bike Path and Beebe Spur to North Derby
Ottauquechee Trail
hits.description:
This trail follows the roads from the Quechee Polo field to the covered bridge at Quechee Falls.

The Eastern half of the trail is along a well maintained mowed grass trail.  In the center section, the trail narrows, following tightly along the side of the road.  In the western part, the trail follows the river allowing beach access, but can often be muddy.  The river below quechee falls is a very popular summertime picnic spot and swimming hole.

hits.name: Long Trail: South Park Rd to Brandon Mountain Rd
hits.description: From Ralston rest shelter to Sunrise shelter. with lunch at David Logan shelter

hits.name: Szymanski Trails
hits.description:
These paths connect the surrounding neighborhoods to Szymanski Park which has tennis and basketball courts and plenty of shade.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces at the north end of the trail along Stonehenge Drive. The nearest designated accessible parking is at Overlook Park, marked with a waypoint. The trail surface is pavement or natural (dirt or grass), and typically at least 3 feet wide. There are wooden bollards along the trail that reduce the width for a short section. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a steep (8-12%) uphill and downhill section from about 0.7 through 1.3 miles near Overlook Drive and Overlook Park. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved sections. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Slate Valley Trails: Fairgrounds Connector, Upper Birdie, Porcupine and Lower Birdie
hits.description: This trail begins at the Country Club Trailhead. There are beautiful trails with views, benches, streams, bridges, slate walkways, and more. It is well marked with maps, signs, and markers. The country club and restaurant are open to the public. There is also a state campground within walking distance. For more information, please visit slatevalleytrails.org.

hits.name: Long Trail to Round Top Shelter
Lake Summit via Ledge Road
hits.description: Nice short hike - a little steep but not too bad. Park at the end of Ledge Road. From there, follow a brook to the Windmill Hill Pinnacle Association Kiosk. At the Kiosk, follow the sign to creature rock, then up the hill.  At the sign for lake peak, turn right for a short hike to the peak. There is a little bit of a view near the top.  Also there is a lean to or campers (reservations through the Windmill Hill Pinnacle Association are required before using).

hits.name: Unknown Pond Trail
hits.description: This trail starts out at the trailhead parking lot and winds its way through a sugaring operation. It quickly leaves the forest roads and travels along the side of one stream and another as it climbs up the hill side. It reaches a junction with a trail leading over to Gore Mountain Trail via the peak, and a trail leading towards the Unknown Pond. This is a newly cut trail heading to the south east.

hits.name: Cady Hill, Zog's, Snake, and Charlie's Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Cady Hill Forest trail network is the flagship trail network managed by the Town of Stowe. These wooded trails are well cared for and very popular, especially with mountain bikers.

Some of the trails are directional, so be sure to travel along the route the suggested direction.

The trails are typically closed during the Vermont mud season in April-Masy.

hits.name: Osmore Pond Loop
hits.description:
This trail follows around the perimeter of Osmore Pond. 

Trail goers navigating with mobility equipment such as a wheelchair or stroller may need assistance throughout this trail because of areas of steep to very steep (over 8%) grades, steep (over 2%) cross grades, uneven terrain, and tread obstacles.

hits.name: Mount Moosalamoo via Oak Ridge Trail
Breadloaf Mountain and Mount Wilson via Emily Proctor Trail
Goshen Mountain
hits.description: This is a winter, backcountry ski trail only zone. There is a marked RASTA skin trail that you can use while ascending the mountain and a variety of options for traveling back downhill.

hits.name: Winooski West Path
hits.description:
This paved trail parallels the Winooski River.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Taylor Street at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved with mostly asphalt (with railings at the bridge) and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

hits.name: Hartness Park Trails
hits.description: There are also trailheads to this area on Dell Road and Woodbury Road.

hits.name: Bristol Trail Network: Full Loop
hits.description:
The Bristol Trail Network is a scenic loop of mostly flat, easy trail, punctuated by a few short but steep inclines with narrow tread.

This trail is designed to have multiple points of access from the Village of Bristol, so it is easy to hike the whole 3 miles or just hike one or two small sections. Users can park on Main Street or along the Town Green and easily walk to any of the trail segments. There is also parking at trailheads on South Street and behind the Fire Station as well as at the High School and the Recreation Park.

hits.name: App Gap to Camel’s Hump via Long Trail
Vast, Front Door, Pinner and Preacher Loop
Boyce Town Forest
hits.description: Gentle hike up an old road through alpine meadow to gentle peak with 270-degree view. Can see Mad River Glen, Mt. Ellen and Sugarbush South. Swimming lake at the bottom.

hits.name: Widow Meadow Loop via Goshen Road to Widow's Clearing to Water Tower Sundown
Windmill Mountain from Grassy Brook Road
Front Door and The Preacher Loop
Brewster River Trail from South Cambridge
hits.description: This trail is open May - November 1st annually.

hits.name: Sterling Gorge Loop via Catamount Trail
hits.description: This trail starts at the house Edson Hill property. Starting the hike here may require that you're a guest of the resort, or pay for a pass.

hits.name: Glen Lake to Moscow Pond
hits.description: Wonderful views of Glen Lake and Moscow Pond.  Plenty of wildlife-especially porcupines (keep the dogs leashed). The trail continues to Half Moon Pond if you have the time.

hits.name: Stark Mountain and Mount Ellen via The Long Trail
hits.description: Start from Appalachian Gap and head south on the Long Trail. The trail  begins climbing out of the gap, crossing over the summit of Stark Mountain and Mount Ellen. Both of these mountains have lifts at the top and look down on the ski runs at Sugarbush Ski Resort. Hikers are asked not to sit on the lifts.

hits.name: Okemo Mountain via Mountain Road, Upper Arrow, Express Lane, Sweet Solitude
East Calais Trail: Calais to Norton Rd
hits.description: This is part of the Calais/Worcester Vermont trail system.  This is Trail C and marked with signage at significant junctions and then white wooden squares with blue arrows or the letter “C” along the route.  Pleasant rolling hike with some rocks, forests, fields and one 1/4 road walk connecting 2 sections of the trail.  Parking at the Curtis Pond parking lot.

hits.name: Hawk Hill Blue and White Trail Loop
Trail Around Middlebury to Chipman Hill
Seyon Lodge via Spruce Mountain Trail
Upper Pond and White School Loop
hits.description: This mtb trail is part of the larger system at Kingdom Trail Association. More information about conditions, fees and membership can be found here: https://www.kingdomtrails.org/

hits.name: Mount Ethan Allen Trail
hits.description: Burnt Rock is totally worth it and a lot of fun! Ethan Allen has a nice perch where you can rest, have a snack and enjoy the view. Ropes, ladder, and great terrain. muddy in spots.

hits.name: St. Johnsbury Blue and Green Trail
Williams Woods Trail
hits.description: Williams Woods may be the best remaining mature valley clayplain forest in the Champlain Valley. This forest type is composed of white oak, red oak, red maple, white pine, shagbark hickory and white ash. Associated species include hemlock, sugar maple, beech and bur oak. Although this forest type once covered thousands of acres in the Champlain Valley, woodlands like these are now rare.

hits.name: Serenity, Locomotion, Vast and #6 Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Barre Town Forest – Millstone Trails Association

hits.name: Cross Vermont Trail
hits.description:
This paved trail goes by baseball diamonds, soccer fields, and a disc golf course. It starts at Williston Road, heads to Old Stage Road and back.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the partially paved parking lots off of North Williston Road at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved with asphalt, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and bleachers along the route for resting.

hits.name: Callagy’s Trail to Catamount Trail Loop
The Long Trail: VT 242 to VT 58
hits.description: This hike goes from VT 242 to VT 58. There are three mountain peaks along this stretch of the long trail.

hits.name: Minor's Loop Trail
hits.description:
These trails begin behind Colchester High School and are widely used to students and staff.

The loop is flat and winds through the forest, this is a good loop for kids and pets.

This is a great place to walk around during the fall when Vermont's famous foliage is at its peak and the forest is filled with color.

hits.name: Killington Loop via Long Trail and Catamount Trail
Long, Sherburne Pass, and Deer Leap Trail Loop
hits.description: Begin by climbing up the Appalachian/Long Trail towards the top of Pico Peak. After turning onto the Sherburne Pass Trail, detour to Pico Peak where there is a shelter frequently used by LT and AT hikers. Descend down Pico to Route 4 and cross the road. Enjoy the view from Deer Leap Rock before finishing the loop.

hits.name: Slate Valley Trails - Hardy Hill Loop
Stevenson Brook, Dalley, and Hedgehog Hill Trail Loop
hits.description: Begin on Stevenson Brook Trail, which closely follows a brook and heads uphill until it meets the Dalley Loop Trail. There is a stream crossing which can be high in the spring or following recent rains so be careful. Continue downhill on the Hedgehog Hill Trail and end with a short walk along the road back to the trailhead.

hits.name: Duck Brook to Buchanan Shelter via Long Trail
River Run and Fox Run Loop
hits.description: This mtb trail is part of the larger system at Kingdom Trail Association. More information about conditions, fees and membership can be found here: https://www.kingdomtrails.org/

hits.name: Paradise Park Loop from Juniper Hill Trailhead
Huntley Meadows Loop
hits.description:
This trail loops around the sports field at Huntley Meadows and starts from the park and ride lot.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the partially parking lot off of Turnpike Road at the north end of the trail. It does not appear to be van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is natural and typically at least 3 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.1 and 0.6 miles when going clockwise. 

Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections and staircase or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type. The staircase is marked with a waypoint and appears to be avoidable by detouring around within the parking lot. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Dutch Hill Loop
hits.description: Visitors have reported that this trail is not well marked so you may want to download the offline map before you go.

hits.name: The Long Trail: Codding Hollow Road to VT 15
hits.description: This section of the long trail goes from Codding Hollow Road (Waterville) to VT 15 (Johnson).  There’s a place to cross over the Lamoille River, but since the water can get very high, you may have to go down Hogback road to connect to 15.

hits.name: Ethan Allen Bike Path, Loop, and Ridge Trail
hits.description:
Ethan Allen Park is one of the oldest urban parks in the United States. It is home to an observation tower built in 1905 that has views of the Winooski River, Lake Champlain, and the surrounding mountains.

The park has a playground near the parking area and is a great place for visitors of all ages.

hits.name: Forester Trail, Mount Belvidere, Long Trail Belvidere Pond
hits.description: Starting from Mine Road this follows the Frost Trail to the Tillotson Hut Camp and then on to the Long Trail running to the Belvidere peak  before descending through the Forest to Belvidere pond. Since this is one of the least travelled sections of the Long Trail, you may have the trail to yourself. Views from the 50 foot fire tower include glimpses of the Green Mountains and Mount Washington.

hits.name: VYCC Trail and Beaver Trail Loop
Fieldstone Loop
hits.description:
The Fieldstone Loop travels over the Browns River, past a fishing pond, through open fields, and the forest.

Mount Mansfield is visible from the park. The trails can be used year-round and the gentle climbs make it great for cross country skiing.

There is a picnic area and pavilion to stop at after hiking.

hits.name: Kilowatt Powerline Trail
hits.description:
This trail goes along the west bank of the Connecticut River north of the Wilder Dam.

Accessibility: There does not appear to be any designated accessible parking in the unpaved lot off of Wilder Damn Road at the start of the trail (middle of the southern half). The nearest designated accessible parking is marked with a waypoint off of Fern Avenue. Both of the spots are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is natural dirt, grass, or asphalt and typically ranges from 2 to 5 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.8 miles before the trail appears to narrow to less than 3 feet. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. There are bleachers and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: St. Michael's College Natural Area Loop
Birds of Vermont Spear Trail
hits.description: This is one of a few trails beginning from the Birds of Vermont Museum. There are hidden games on the trail, as well as a lush woodland setting to enjoy.

hits.name: Bombardier Inner Loop
hits.description:
South of the Milton Municipal Building, library, and fire department.

Accessibility: There is at least one designated accessible space in the paved parking lot along Park Place at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is packed gravel or natural (dirt/grass) and typically at least 3 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.2, 0.5, 0.6, and 0.8 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type. There are benches and picnic tables in the park for resting.

hits.name: Tam Sidewinder to Chipman Hill Summit
Silver Lake and Sugar Hill Reservoir Loop
Winooski East Path
hits.description:
A paved trail along the east side of the Winooski River. 

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces along Stone Cutters Way at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved with mostly asphalt or cement, and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Vermont College of Fine Arts Slate Quarry Trail
Stratton Mountain, Stratton Pond, and Bourne Pond Loop
Sucker Brook and Stewart Trail Loop
Woodpecker, Troll Road, X-Mas Tree, Duke's Loop and Workout
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Catamount, Billings Road, Maple Run, and Marston Trails Loop
hits.description: This trail starts at the house Edson Hill property. Starting the hike here may require that you're a guest of the resort, or pay for a pass.

hits.name: Merck Antone - Schenck - Gallop Road Loop
Outerbound, Big Boss, Sugar Maple, River Run, Heavens Loop
Quechee Green Trail
hits.description: Mostly flat loop trail around the quechee green.  Popular area for families and dogs.

hits.name: Laraway Mountain Trail [CLOSED]
hits.description:
The hike is not just a means to an end. Good views and features.

This hike is most certainly a sleeper. Nestled in between Belvidere and Waterville at the end of Coddling Hollow Road, the meager elevation change and innocuous looking topography make it appear uninteresting. March up the fairly untrammeled path and you will find trout lillies growing right in the middle of the trail and big red trilliums on the side. The view from up high gives you a nearly 180-degree view centered southwest.

1,500 feet in 3.6 miles doesn't make this section of the Long Trail seem all that daunting, and it is not, but many avid hikers will overlook it for this reason and they should not. The summit is treed, so there may not be any alpine vegetation, but one definitely experiences nearly every other variety of flora and geology on the way up. Starting from the difficult-to-find parking lot, the trail simply resembles a disused logging road among many other much more disused logging roads. 

The logging road section quickly changes though after crossing a mountain stream and heading more sharply up. It is at this point that one divines the topography of the area: you are heading up the left side of a basin, crawling up the ridge as it materializes. Soon the trail becomes pretty narrow and more seasonal waterways appear. The trail has a few wet spots, but they are nothing to write home about. 

Soon after the trail narrows significantly, the trout lillies and trilliums give way to more typical trail paving: roots and big rocks. At one point, you will find yourself in a deep and seasonal though and largely antedeluvian-seeming flume, with rocks on either side, with the sound of yesterday's rain ticking away. Certainly though this isn't the end, there are also long, and massive rock overhangs furnishing more than a tickling of water. At this point, one can see a southward preview of the view from the lookout.

Laraway Lookout is very obvious on the Long Trail, offering unobstructed views mainly of the Mansfield and Sterling ranges, plus peaks of Lake Champlain. If you like, continue four tenths of a mile to Laraway Mountain's treed summit. Return the way you came.

hits.name: Camel's Hump View Trail
hits.description:
A quick, easy gravel loop through a forest that includes a scenic view of Camel's Hump. 

It's a good spot for those looking to snap a photo of the mountain, or for just sitting and enjoying the view. The bench that offers the best view of the mountain is in the upper east portion of the trail.

hits.name: Geprags Park Trail
hits.description:
Again, A wonderful asset for trail lovers and dog lovers and in the winter, if there's substantial snow a good place to practice BC XC skiing. 
Recent upgrades are a newish trail going off to the northwest with switchbacks and a little loop at the end called Summit Loop. 
I did all trails for the first time and it took an hour and a half and was 3.3 miles about. First time ever.

hits.name: Birds of Vermont Gale's and Bob's Trail
hits.description: This is one of a few walking trails open to the public at the Birds of Vermont Museum. This route starts with Gail’s Trail, climbing to the top. Bob’s Trail will bring you back to the start. This trail offers a lovely mix of different trees and terrain. Please not that no are dogs allowed.

hits.name: Fox Run, Violet's, Old Web's, Border, Bearback, West Bench, Hog Back and Sidewinder
hits.description: This mtb trail is part of the larger system at Kingdom Trail Association. More information about conditions, fees and membership can be found here: https://www.kingdomtrails.org/

hits.name: Laughlin Trail
hits.description: The Laughlin Trail and Lingelbach Trail guide visitors along the Ottauquechee River, with views of Dewey’s Pond.

hits.name: Mount Mansfield via Nebraska Notch, Long Trail, Sunset Ridge, CCC Road, and Frost Trail Loop
hits.description:
Star from Stevensville Road and head up the Nebraska Notch Trail. Take the Clara Bow or LT to Taylor Lodge and for bonus views, climb up the little hill to the overlook in front of Taylor Lodge. 

Backtrack up the LT to the Forehead and proceed over the ridge to the Chin. Backtrack again (briefly) to the intersection w/ the Sunset Ridge Trail. Take that back down to CCC road until you hit Maple Ridge. The last climb for the day is up to Maple Ridge (nice view), then back down the Frost trail back to Stevensville Road.

hits.name: Nowland Farm Preserve Trail
hits.description: This is an easy loop through calming nature preserve lands. This trail can at times be wet and muddy, so users are recommended to wear good footwear.

hits.name: Slate Valley Trails - Big Top to Ringmaster
LaPlatte Headwaters Public Trail
hits.description: Nice, well groomed trails through woods and Hidden Meadow. Including Bissonette Loop and Copp-Welch Loop.

hits.name: Snow Goose, Saddle Trail, and Sugar Maple Loop
Woodside Loop
hits.description:
An easy, level trail with a few stairs and steps. In the summer months, there is lots of tree cover and shade. The trail circles around a lake and wetlands and passes closely by the Winooski River.

No biking and dogs must be kept on a leash. A nice quick secluded retreat into nature.

hits.name: Lemon's Haunt to Ruthie's Run to Sam's Run Loop
Midlands Trail Network
hits.description:
The route on this page is actually a combination of several trails including Stonewall, Barbwire, Snare, and Chainlink.

This area is maintained by the Brewster River Mountain Bike Club.

hits.name: Windmill Mountain via Grassy Brook Road
hits.description:
Beginning just outside the small town of Brookline, hike up Windmill Hill Trail before meeting the ridgeline. Head north on the ridge crossing over a spot with a view of Mount Monadnock to the east in neighboring New Hampshire. Continue to the peak of Windmill Mountain before retracing your steps.

The area is maintained by the Putney Mountain Association.

hits.name: Susan Bacher Memorial Trail
hits.area_name: Helen W. Buckner Memorial Preserve at Bald Mountain
hits.description:
It is hard to imagine a more inspiring piece of Vermont landscape than the Helen W. Buckner Memorial Preserve. Encircled by the southernmost end of Lake Champlain to the west and south, the Poultney River to the east, and Bald Mountain to the north, this is an isolated piece of rural Vermont not reached by a road until 1934. Today, it remains a less visited part of the state, where rare snakes, peregrine falcons, and five-lined skinks (the only lizard found in the state) still outnumber human visitors.

The Buckner Preserve is the most ecologically diverse natural area managed by the Conservancy in Vermont, and is home to 11 uncommon or rare-in-Vermont animal species, 18 species of rare or uncommon plants, and at least 15 distinct natural community types. Here paddlers can explore undeveloped Lake Champlain shoreline, the secluded twists and turns of the Lower Poultney River, and, in high water, floodplain forests and marshes. Trail walkers can move quickly from the lake and river shore, up through gently rolling hay meadows, cross stony talus slopes, and ascend cliffs topped by a dry oak-hickory-hophornbeam forest.

From the cliffs there are sweeping vistas of the narrowing south end of Lake Champlain, the Poultney River, and lake-influenced wetlands. Bald Mountain adds its indomitable character to the preserve with its stark cliffs and talus slopes, home to peregrine falcon nests and a unique assemblage of amphibians and reptiles found nowhere else in Vermont.

hits.name: Shaw Mountain Loop
hits.description: The limestone uplift of Shaw Mountain rises over 500 feet from the surrounding land, and is a dominant landscape feature in Benson and adjacent West Haven, Vermont. Shaw Mountain Natural Area supports 11 distinct plant communities, including a shrub swamp, vernal pools, an oak-hickory forest, and a calcareous outcrop community, in addition to 15 rare plant species.

hits.name: 127 Bike Path and Intervale Bike Path Trail Loop
hits.description:
This flat loop along the Winooski River circles the Ethan Allen Homestead and passes the site of the Black Snake Affair. 

The Black Snake Affair was an incident where a Vermont militia engaged a smuggling ship, The Black Snake, in a gunboat fight on the Winooski River.

The Ethan Allen Homestead also offers tours, for more info please visit: https://ethanallenhomestead.org/visit-us/

hits.name: Mother's Day, AC/DC, A-Day, and Lung Ta Path Loop
Whiteface, Madonna, Morse, and Spruce Peaks via Long Trail
Long Trail: Butternut Mountain to Eden Crossing
Collins Perley Sports Center
hits.description:
This loop goes around the sports fields, track, and fitness center.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Fisher Pond Road in the center of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved with asphalt and typically at least 3 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and bleachers along the route for resting.

hits.name: Lamoille Valley Rail Trail: Sheldon Junction to Swanton
Hundred Acre Woods Logging Loop and Blue Trail
Mount Ephraim via Dutton District Road
Church Path and Burham Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Church Path begins near the East Branch of the Passumsic River and leads through open fields and the forest before crossing Route 114. Please use caution when crossing this busy road. 

The trail then turns into Burham which is a directional trail, so hikers and bikers should follow the route shown here.

hits.name: Baby Stark Mountain, Molly Stark Mountain, Burnt Rock, and Mount Ethan Allen via Long Trail
hits.description:
This section of the Long Trail crosses over Mt. Ethan Allen, Burnt Rock Mountain, and several lesser peaks. 

There are two shelters between Montclair Glen and Appalachian Gap. There are several good views, boreal forest, and northern hardwood forest. A nice section of the trail for a one or two day hike.

hits.name: The Long Trail:  VT 58 to VT 118
hits.description: This trail goes from Hazen Notch Road (VT 58), which is closed in the winter, to VT 118. This is a beautiful stretch that has three mountains - Haystack, Tillotson, and Belvidere. There’s also a cabin called Tillotson camp.

hits.name: Woodpecker, Troll Road, X-Mas Tree, Duke's Loop, Chicadee, and Workout Loop
hits.description:
This is one of many cross-country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

The trails are mostly maintained for cross-country skiing, with a few trails open for snowshoeing. The lodge can be reached at (802) 442-2575 to learn what snowshoe trails are open. Hiking is not permitted during the winter operating season to protect the maintained ski trails.

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Paddock Hill and Long Pond
hits.description:
The Conservancy manages 1,500 feet of shoreline around this remote, undeveloped 99-acre pond, a rarity in Vermont. A large, relatively undisturbed cedar swamp at the southern end of the lake consists of roughly 60 acres of white cedar with little to no woody understory.  A damp, dark, mossy carpet covers the forest floor.  Long Pond is surrounded by a northern hardwood forest and includes habitat for such birds as the common loon and mammals like the river otter and bobcat. 

Together, the swamp, lake, and surrounding forests support several boreal bird species, including boreal chickadee, cape may warbler, rusty blackbird, and loons.  In addition, the cedar swamp likely provides winter cover for small mammals, such as the masked and short tail shrews, voles and mice.

hits.name: Meach Cove
hits.description:
Meach Cove Farms is a privately-owned farm that combines agriculture, research, and education. Trails are available for hiking and biking to visitors. Users have noted that you need to register for a parking permit beforehand. Please contact the park for more information. 

When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on the private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

Accessibility: There are no designated accessible spaces in the gravel street parking off of Depot Road at the north end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is dirt or gravel road with grass in the middle. It is typically at least 12 feet wide. There is a double track along most of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 1.8 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.

hits.name: Long Trail: Lincoln Gap to Middlebury Gap
hits.description:
This section of the Long Trail is 17 miles and traverses the summits of the “Vermont Presidentials” including Mt Grant, Cleveland, Wilson, and Roosevelt. Throw in Breadloaf Mountain and you’ve also summited two of the New England Hundred Highest peaks (Wilson and Breadloaf). 

This point-to-point hike can be done either southbound or northbound. Set a car shuttle and you’re good to go. There are four shelters on this section so it can be done as a day hike or an overnight. There is plenty of water, opportunities to see wildlife, and several good views. A very pleasant section of the Long Trail!

hits.name: Tweedle Dee and Tweedle Dum Loop via Chipman Hill Top Trail
Megan's Loop
hits.description: Went between the Cricket Hill Road Trailhead and the LUHS trailhead. Tried to find the whole “Meagan’s Way” trail on the way back, but the majority of the trail was the “Killer Hill” trail.

hits.name: Bolton Mountain and Puffer Shelter via Bryant, Birch, Raven's Wind, and Long Trail
hits.description:
From the base of Bolton Valley Ski Resort, start a steady climb up to the summit of Bolton Mountain. Continue past the summit for just less than half a mile to reach the Puffer Shelter on the Long Trail.

This three-sided shelter was built in 1975 and looks out to spectacular views of the surrounding mountains.

hits.name: North Springfield Kettle Bog Outer Bog Trail
hits.description:
The North Springfield Bog trail is a short wooded walking trail that leads to and around a boreal kettle bog on town property. A compact boardwalk through the bog allows close-up viewing of the many interesting bog plants, including some remarkably large pitcher plants. The loop around the bog goes through surrounding spruce, pine, and hemlock groves.  

The trail to the bog is a clear path. The trails around the bog are marked with occasional white blazes on trees or posts. The track in this listing is for the Outer Bog trail. An alternative Red Pine Trail parallels this trail just up the bank.

hits.name: Bill Magill, Pines and Widow Maker
hits.description: This mtb trail is part of the larger system at Kingdom Trail Association. More information about conditions, fees and membership can be found here: https://www.kingdomtrails.org/

hits.name: Bear Brook Trail
hits.description: Uphill all the way just about. No big views but nice in the woods. Have to cross a stream in beginning

hits.name: Bog Pond Trail
hits.description: Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

hits.name: Sunrise Lake
hits.description:
This trail is along the roadway. There may not be a shoulder or dedicated bike lane. Wearing a helmet, bright clothing, and using lights and flagging is always recommended when sharing space with motor vehicles. 

Accessibility: It is unknown if there are any designated accessible spaces in the parking lot off of Sunset Lake Road at the south end of the trail. The closest known designated accessible parking may be over 5 miles away. The trail surface is asphalt or packed dirt and gravel, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (5-12%) uphill and downhill sections after about a half-mile of going north, outbound. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type.

hits.name: Noodle's Revenge, Luvin It, Bubba, and Middle Ravine Loop
Maiden, Eagle, Back Door, Dragon, Lost, Passing the Horizon and International Loop
Airport Park Loop
hits.description:
This loop heads around the sports fields/courts at Airport Park.

Accessibility: There are at least 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of Colchester Point Road at the start of the trail by the Recreation Department Building. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved with cement and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is all gentle (up to 3%). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Long Trail: State Route 103 to State Route 125
Beaver Pond Trail
hits.description: First .3 of trail is wide logging road. The rest is narrower wooded trail until you reach Beaver Pond!

hits.name: Indian Brook Reservoir [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description:
Please note that this trail is only open to residents of Essex. A permit is required to enter.

It is an easy walk, or if you want a easy hike. The well maintained, and well groomed main trail which goes around the reservoir hold views of nature and is good or birding in places. 

There are some smaller trails which can be accessed in places. One of the lower parking lots has a loop that pushes back into the woods and is marked.

There is another small trail that runs along the road to the upper parking lot.

There is a bathroom located at the upper parking lot.

You can hike, walk, swim, and so on. Fun for the whole family, including your dog.

hits.name: Branch Pond via Branch Pond Trail
hits.description:
From Kelley Stand Road, begin at a small parking area for about 3 cars. Follow the Bourne Pond Trail which rolls in elevation towards the pond. 

Enjoy the scenery at the pond before returning along the same path made of soft dirt and pine needles. There are some exposed roots and rocks to be mindful of.

hits.name: Bald Peak Trail
hits.description:
Part of the Pittsford Trail Network. The trail is a quick ascent to two different vistas. The north vista looks out onto Pittsford and North Chittenden, and the south vista looks down into Rutland. The south vista also has bolted rock climbing and bouldering options. 

The gully between the vistas leads into the ice caves area, but watch your footing as there are treacherous openings between the rocks.

hits.name: Woodpecker, E-Z Way, Troll Road and Duke's Loop
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Bald Mountain via Mad Brook Trail
Barre Path
hits.description:
This paved trail starts from Bridge Street in South Barre and heads to Fairview Street in Barre and back.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the at the south end of the trail. The nearest designated accessible parking is at the intersection of Bridge Street and South Barre Road or off of Parkside Terrace, both marked with waypoints. The trail surface is paved with mostly asphalt, and typically at least 5 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to steep (6-12%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.0, 0.6, and 0.8 miles when going northbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. Sections of pavement may also be broken or uneven where some users may need assistance. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Awasiwi Trail
hits.description:
This trail has several footbridges and goes through the well-shaded Potash Brook.

Accessibility: There are at least 5 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Dorset Street at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is natural, paved, or wooden footbridges and typically at least 3 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is from 0.6 through 1.3 miles. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections between about 0.3 through 0.9 miles when going eastbound. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved, uneven, and potentially soft areas.

hits.name: Shattuck Mountain Loop Trail
hits.description:
The Shattuck Mtn. Loop Trail is a moderately difficult trail located at 1331, Waterville Mountain Road in Bakersfield.  It is a little over a mile loop with 2 other trails branching off, the Waterfall Trail (Red) and the Lookout Trail (Blue).  The Waterfall Trail leads to a small seasonal waterfall and the Lookout Trail leads to a beautiful overlook of the surrounding mountains.  The Loop Trail is accessed just up the drive from the newly built parking area.

If using Google Maps, be sure it is leading you to Waterville Rd in Bakersfield before departing.

hits.name: Laraway Mountain via Davidson and Long Trail
hits.description:
The Davidson Trail connects to the LT and onward to Laraway Mountain. Laraway Mountain is home to a shelter maintained by the Green Mountain Club for backpackers to stay at. 

The trail can be very buggy in the spring and summer months, so bug spray is strongly encouraged!

hits.name: Heaven's Bench, Vast, Connector, Bill Magill, River Run and Fox Run
hits.description: This mtb trail is part of the larger system at Kingdom Trail Association. More information about conditions, fees and membership can be found here: https://www.kingdomtrails.org/

hits.name: Shelburne Farms to Lone Tree Hill Loop [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description: Dogs are not allowed on the property. May-November there is a fee for entry onto the property. When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future. Visit shelburnefarms.org for more info about the organization.

hits.name: Church Path, Park Loop, Ridge Run, and X-Mas Tree Loop Trail
hits.description:
Begin near the banks of the Passumsic River and follow trails through open fields and the forest. These trails are non technical mountain bike trails that can be enjoyed by mountain bikers of all ability levels.

Just off of the Christmas Tree Loop there is a pump track for mountain bikers to use.

hits.name: Halloween Tree, Snail, and Lower Beacon Trail Loop
hits.description:
Begin in a field and then enter into the woods and begin to climb up the side of Mount Anthony. The trail has many switchback and turns that make for a fun bike ride of trail run.

Like many trails in Vermont, expect this trail to be closed mid-March until Memorial Day weekend to protect the trails during mud season.

hits.name: Bemis, River Run and Fox Run Loop
hits.description: This mtb trail is part of the larger system at Kingdom Trail Association. More information about conditions, fees and membership can be found here: https://www.kingdomtrails.org/

hits.name: Widow's Clearing Trail
hits.description: The Google Maps app have can have difficulty locating the trailhead, the location can be found at: https://goo.gl/maps/bPeNsgCdz3gDiaXZ8

hits.name: Newport Bike Path and Beebe Spur: Prouty Campground
Indian Brook Outer Loop [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description: You need a pass to get in, requiring you to be a resident of Essex.

hits.name: Lake Mansfield, Long, and Bolton-Trapp Trail Loop
hits.description:
Begin near Lake Mansfield and climb up towards Nebraska Notch and onto the Long Trail. The route passes Taylor Lodge maintained by the Green Mountain Club and over the ridge crossing Mount Mayo.

Eventually, begin to descend via the Bolton-Trapp Trail which parallels Miller Brook before returning to the trailhead.

hits.name: Gore Mountain via East Trail
hits.area_name: Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge - Nulhegan Basin Division
hits.description:
The East Trail to the summit of Gore Mountain begins in Silvio O. Conte National Fish and Wildlife Refuge and follows blue blazes to the summit of the mountain which has an old cabin on top.

The best views are about a half-mile from the summit along the ridgeline. 

The trail can be muddy following recent rains.

hits.name: #6, Westside, Holy Ghost, Serenity, Locomotion, Capital, and Vast Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Barre Town Forest – Millstone Trails Association
hits.description:
Barre Town Forest is a 370-acre park located on the property of an old granite mine. The mine was established in 1790 and was operational for over 100 years.
The trails wind through the woods and above the quarry ponds.

Hunting is permitted, so remember to wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.

Remember to pack out everything you bring into the forest.

hits.name: Bill Ballard Trail
hits.description:
The Bill Ballard Trail passes along the "Grand Canyon of Norwich" created by a creek running into Charles Brown Brook.

Along the rolling path, you will cross over creeks, bridges, up stone steps, and past old stone walls. There are also some benches that are great spots to stop and snack before continuing on.

hits.name: Big Deer Mountain via Coldwater Brook, Big Deer Mountain, and Hosmer Brook Trail Loop
hits.description:
The trail begins with a very easy grade through the woods and past the remains of an old sawmill.

The 1/4 mile to the summit of Big Deer is steep, but once up top there are two beautiful vistas, one overlooking Lake Groton, the other looking east to New Hampshire and the Whites.

hits.name: Arms Forest Loop
hits.description:
Arms Forest is close to Rock Point School and Burlington High School and is widely used by students and staff.

The forest is home to an old quarry and historically was used to harvest timber and graze livestock.

The property was a dairy farm until the early 1960s when it was purchased to build a new high school.

hits.name: Buchanan Mountain via The Long Trail
hits.description:
Begin at the parking area on top of Jay Peak Pass along VT Route 242.

The trail begins with a climb up towards Gilpin Mountain South Peak, then continues along the ridge line crossing Domeys Dome and eventually reaching Buchanan Mountain. This is slow section of trail with some large rocks and exposed roots, good footwear is recommended.

hits.name: Green Mountain, Long, Baker Peak, and Griffith Lake Trail Loop
hits.description: This is a good backpacking loop beginning by crossing over Green Mountain and past Little Rock Pond. Follow the Long Trail/Appalachian Trail towards Baker Peak. Follow Baker Peak Trail towards Griffith Lake. The lake has a social trail around it, not an established and maintained USFS trail. Join the AT/LT again and head back towards the trailhead.

hits.name: Shea's Rebellion, Mountain Trail and Woodpecker Loop
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Monadnock Mountain [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description:
To access, park at the fishing access across from the White House south of the bridge. Stay to the left of the White House on the lawn and walk towards the trail head (marked by yellow blazes).

This is an awesome, but challenging hike. You will climb straight up and down the mountain. Great views from the top once you climb the 70 steps of lookout tower!

hits.name: Catamount, Long, Goat, and Maple Trail Loop
hits.description:
Begin off the access road leading to Bolton Valley Ski Resort. Head up the Catamount Trail passing the Bolton Lodge. For more info about staying in the lodge, visit: https://www.greenmountainclub.org/about/gmc-rental-cabins/bolton-lodge/

At the top of the ridge, follow the Long Trail to Harrington's View. Backtrack a short distance and follow the Goat Path and Maple Loop back down.

hits.name: Tatooine, Millenium Falcon, and Han Solo Loop
hits.description: As a part of the Sleepy Hollow Bike/Ski Center, there is an entrance fee to use this trail. For more information, please see https://www.skisleepyhollow.com/mt-biking-running/

hits.name: Woodpecker, Troll Road, Whistle Pig, Mountain Trail and Shea's Rebellion
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Big Deer Mountain via Coldwater Brook Trail
hits.description:
The trail begins with a very easy grade through beautiful woods and along the brook. Remains of a sawmill are visible from the trail. 

The last quarter mile to the summit is steep, but once up top there are two beautiful vistas, one overlooking Lake Groton, the other looking east to New Hampshire and the Whites. 

The eastward view is off the trail and hard to find. There’s a barely visible path just before you hit the giant erratic. Overall, the trail is well-marked and affords beautiful scenery. A hidden gem of Vermont hiking.

hits.name: Belvidere Mountain and Tillotson Camp via Long Trail
hits.description: From Belvidere Road, follow the Long Trail for about 3 miles to Belvidere Mountain. The summit has a fire tower offering sweeping views of the area. Continue along the Long Trail towards Lockwood Pond and Tillotson Camp. The Tillotson Camp shelter is a good place to stop and rest before making the return trek. The shelter has a privy and space for about 8 people.

hits.name: Eaton Brook and Larry's Legacy Trail Loop
hits.description:
This series of double-track trails are located behind Hazen Union High School. The first trails were built in 2002 and additional trails were built in 2009.

The trails are peaceful and wooded, and plant and bird identification lists are available at the trailhead.

Please be mindful of trail conditions during mud season.

hits.name: Burnt Mountain [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description: Hiking is permitted from mid-May to mid-November. In winter, a trail fee is charged for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Winter access is from the cross country ski center on the Hazen's Notch Road.

hits.name: Over Yonder Loop via Middle Ravine, Fusters, and Noodle's Revenge
Inner Peace, Heaven's 11, Back Run, Beaver Pond, VYCCenic, and Outerbound Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Jay Community Recreational Centre Trails are a well-maintained series of trails built to encourage the community of Jay and its visitors to get outside and experience the natural landscape of the area year-round.

Along the trail there is a mountain bike progression park, composting privy, gazebo, and benches to stop at.

hits.name: Grand View Lodge Rd to Peggys Pond
hits.description: As of May 29, 2020, users have reported that the pond has been drained.

hits.name: Bill Ballard, Blue Ribbon, and Parcel 5 Trail Loop
hits.description:
Begin on the Bill Ballard Trail which will take you by the "Grand Canyon of Norwich," created by a stream flowing into Charles Brown Brook.

Cross over Beaver Meadow Road and climb up the Blue Ribbon Trail before descending down Parcel 5 back to the parking area. The trails on the east side of Beaver Mountain Road are open to mountain bikers.

hits.name: Robinson Hill Road and Lower Falls Trail Loop
hits.description:
Start on Robinson Hill Road in the parking area at the top of the Lower Falls trail and walk south on Robinson Hill Road to the unmarked entrance to some of the biking trails with blue posts. 

The trail follows along the cliffside to the east. Meander south then take a left bend meandered back north. Eventually, the trail connects back to the Lower Falls Trail.  

Spectacular spring wildflowers such as spring beauty, Hepatica, Trillium, and Troutlilly.

hits.name: Martin Covered Bridge Trail
hits.description:
This small park has trails passing through a pasture and into a forested area.

Begin on the side of Route 2 and cross over the Martin Covered Bridge. The bridge was built in 1890 and crosses the Winooski River. Today it is the only wooden covered bridge left in Marshfield, the bridge is open to foot traffic only.

hits.name: Haystack Mountain [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description:
At an elevation of 2712 feet, Haystack Mountain is located just outside of Willoughby State Forest in Westmore. The low, but rugged, peak is aptly named for its abrupt sides that climb steeply from all directions. The peak is accessible by two trails, the North Trail and South Trail, and offers excellent local views towards Long Pond, Bald Mountain and beyond in several directions. North Trail: Approximately 0.6 miles past the boat access at Long Pond, the North Trail on Haystack begins at a small parking area on Long Pond Road. Parking is limited, so please take care to keep the road clear. From the trailhead, the trail climbs moderately through open hardwoods for some time before ascending steeply onto the summit knoll and intersecting one of several short spur trails. To the right, a spur trail leads to a western lookout with views of Long Pond, Lake Willoughby and beyond. Continuing straight, North Trail soon reaches the summit (marked with a large rock pile) and the junction with the South Trail. 

South Trail: This trail leaves the summit of Haystack Mountain and soon reaches two lookouts, one to the east and one to the south. Continuing down the trail quickly drops into mixed woods and follows moderate grades back to Long Pond Road. From here, it is a short walk back to the North Trail parking area (approx. 1.2 mi.). 

SUMMARY: Haystack summit to Long Pond Road, approx. 1.0 mi., <1hr. (Rev. 1/2 hr.); Haystack Loop: North Trail to South Trail w/ Long Pond Rd. walk, approx. 3.0 mi., 2 hrs.

hits.name: Prospect Mountain Loop
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Prospect Mountain via Shea's Rebellion and Mountain Trail
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Hogback, Sucker Brook, and Stewart Trail Loop
Bottom Up and Last Call Trail Loop
hits.description: Begin from the parking area behind the Kingdom Trails Welcome Center and follow the path through the woods and cross over Maple Lane. After crossing the road Bottom-Up meets Last Call. Last call has a few switchbacks and short but steep hills. The trail loops back around to Bottom-Up creating a lollipop.

hits.name: Hogback, Halfdan Kuhnle, Sucker Brook, and Stewart Trail Loop
hits.description: Begin on the Hogback Loop passing between Hogback Mountain and Romance Mountain, then begin to climb up towards Romance. After reaching the high point, descend down towards Sucker Brook. The trail winds through the woods and close to the brook. The Stewart Trail will finish the loop and head towards the trailhead.

hits.name: Big Deer and Little Deer Mountain Loop
hits.description:
The trail begins with a very easy grade through beautiful woods and along the brook. Remains of a sawmill are visible from the trail. 

The last quarter mile to the summit of Big Deer is steep, but once up top there are two beautiful vistas, one overlooking Lake Groton, the other looking east to New Hampshire and the Whites. 

Head back down Big Deer past Osmore Pond and up Little Deer Mountain. Take the Telephone Line Trail back towards the trailhead and Groton Nature Center.

hits.name: Crosstown Road and Long Loop Trail
hits.description:
Parking is available near Brookfield Rd and Darling Rd. These trails can be closed during the Vermont mud season beginning when the snow starts to melt and ending around Memorial Day.

The trail is rolling single track passing through Berlin Town Forest, Montpelier City Forest, and Boyer State Forest.

hits.name: Ghoshen Brook, Moose Loop, Blackberry Run, and Window's Clearing Trail Loop
hits.description:
Moosalamoo National Recreation Area is a nearly 16,000-acre area with abundant multi-use trails.

Climb up the Goshen Brook Trail and Moose Trail to the high point of the loop. The route then travels over some rolling terrain before descending down the Window's Clearing Trail back to the parking area.

hits.name: Goshen Dam Trail from Silver Lake Campground
Long, Battell, and USFS 349 Trail Loop
hits.description:
A nice 6 plus mile loop incorporating Lincoln Gap Rd, the Long and Battell Trails, and USFS road 349. 

Continue north on the Long trail from Battell Shelter for 0.8 miles to the summit of Mt. Abraham if you like. The shelter is a great place to stop and rest before finishing the loop.

hits.name: North Loop
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Sugarbush, Ridge and Limber Jim Trail
Mountain Top Inn Trail [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description: You must be a guest of the inn to use this trail system.

hits.name: Prospect Mountain
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Flag Hill and Hawkins Mountain via Cross Rivendell Trail
hits.description:
Begin at the intersection of Chelsea and Taylor Valley Road and head towards Flag Hill and the Cross Rivendell Trail. Retrace your steps back to the car, then head out and back to Hawkins Mountain. Flag Hill has a nice picnic spot up top. 

The Hawkins Mountain Trail is not as well marked and difficult to follow. Downloading the map is helpful for navigating.

hits.name: The Long Trail Northern Terminus via VT Route 105
hits.description:
From Vermont Route 105, begin with a 600 foot climb to the top of Carleton Mountain. The summit is mostly wooded. Continue to descend the mountain heading towards the border. A small monolith monument marks the United States/Canadian border.

For Long Trail hikers heading north, this is the final stretch of their 270+ mile journey.

hits.name: Beaver Run, Rock and Roll, Harrington Ridge, Vortex, and Holy Roller Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Barre Town Forest – Millstone Trails Association
hits.description:
Barre Town Forest is a 370-acre park located on the property of an old granite mine. The mine was established in 1790 and was operational for over 100 years. Today, the area is reclaimed for recreational use. The tight winding turns of the Vortex Trail is a fun challenge for mountain bikers.

Hunting is permitted, so remember to wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.

hits.name: Mount Roosevelt, Mount Wilson, and Skylight Pond
hits.description:
Hikers will follow the Clark Brook Trail into the Breadloaf Wilderness which meets up with the Long Trail on the ridge line.

Once hikers gain the ridge, they will cross the summit of Roosevelt and Wilson on the way to Skylight Pond.

Skylight Pond has a shelter for backpackers and Long Trail thru hikers to use.

hits.name: Lake Champlain via Shelburne Farms [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description: Dogs are not allowed May-November and must be leashed Nov-May as this is a working farm. May-November there is a fee for entry onto the property. When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future. Visit shelburnefarms.org for more info about the organization.

hits.name: Eaton Brook, Shepard's, and Larry's Legacy Trail Loop
hits.description:
This series of double-track trails are located behind Hazen Union High School. The first trails were built in 2002 and additional trails were built in 2009.

The trails are peaceful and wooded, and plant and bird identification lists are available at the trailhead.

Please be mindful of trail conditions during mud season.

hits.name: Misty Meadow, Riverside, Solitude, and Rodgers Ridge Trail Loop
hits.description:
Hikers are asked to park in the lot closest to Brookside Drive during school hours. There is an informational kiosk near this parking area.

The trails enter the woods, through an open area then along Browns River. The trail then begins to head back towards the school along Rodgers Brook and the perimeter of a field before arriving back at the parking area.

hits.name: Loggers Loop and Old Tavern Pass Trail
hits.description: This trail network is located just outside of the town of Jeffersonville. Begin from a trailhead off Canyon Road, walk down Canyon Road for a short distance before reaching the trailhead. The trail walks along the perimeter of a field and through the woods. The colors can be absolutely striking here in the fall!

hits.name: X-Mas Tree, Duke's Loop, Workout and Troll Road
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: East Mountain via Radar Road [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description: This abandoned site leftover from the Cold War Era is on privately owned land and inaccessible to the general public.

hits.name: Woodpecker, Troll Road, Loose Moose, Workout, Longshot, Mountain Trail and Hawthorn
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: X-Mas Tree, Loose Moose, Workout, Hill 2290, E-Z Way and Troll Road
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Holbrook Trail
hits.description:
Begin from a small parking area off Route 122. This trail leads to Round Pond and Long Pond with some scenic cliffs above the ponds. The area is open to fishing, anglers should be familiar with Vermont fishing regulations.

Hunting is permitted, so hikers should wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.
