hits.name: Lincoln Park Trail
hits.description:
This trail goes around Woodbridge Town Square. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Dickenson Avenue at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. This parking lot has been marked with a waypoint. The trail surface is paved concrete, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Brookside, Misty Meadows, Solitude, Riverside, and Express Lane Trail Loop
hits.description:
Hikers are asked to park in the lot closest to Brookside Drive during school hours. There is an informational kiosk near this parking area.

The trail follows a field and runs parallel with Brookside Drive and then along an athletic field. The trail enters the forest and along Rodgers Brook. Turn back towards the school, along a field, and then behind the elementary school.

hits.name: Woodpecker, E-Z Way, Workout, Longshot, Hill 2290, Slingshot, and Boomerang
hits.description:
This is one of many cross country ski trails located at Prospect Mountain. Prospect Mountain is open to all ages, from 9am to 5pm (or sundown) for cross country skiing and snowshoeing. Please see more information here: https://prospectmountain.com/

In the non-winter months, trails are available for hiking, walking and running.

hits.name: Scrag Mountain [PRIVATE PROPERTY]
hits.description: Beautiful hike up from the Northfield side. Great foliage views from the top.

hits.name: Holbrook and Summit Trail Loop
hits.description:
Begin from a small parking area off Route 122. This trail leads to Round Pond and Long Pond before looping up to the top of Big Rock Hill. 

The area is open to fishing, anglers should be familiar with Vermont fishing regulations.

Hunting is permitted, so hikers should wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.

hits.name: Willow Park Trail
hits.description:
Willow Park is home to athletic fields for local youth sports, a pump track for mountain bikes, and a playground.

A walkway made of bricks is in place with engravings with the names of all of those who donated to help make it a reality.

This flat path circles around the park along the perimeter of the fields.

hits.name: Cobb Town East Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Cobb Town Forest was donated to the town of Stratford in 1962 by longtime resident Dr. Gardner Cobb. The east loop passes through the woods but it is largely a wetland area. Biking is permitted but not best on this side of the forest.

Hunting is permitted, so remember to wear blaze orange if visiting during hunting season.

hits.name: Fen Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Cobb Town Forest was donated to the town of Stratford in 1962 by longtime resident Dr. Gardner Cobb. The Fen Trail is known for the countless number of lady slippers that bloom alongside the trail each year in late June.

Hunting is permitted, so wear blaze orange if visiting during hunting season.

hits.name: Cobb Hill and Fen Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Cobb Town Forest was donated to the town of Stratford in 1962 by longtime resident Dr. Gardner Cobb. The loop passes through hardwood forest and past wetland areas. Bog boards are in place to travel through the wetland areas without disturbing the fragile ecosystem.

Hunting is permitted, so wear blaze orange during hunting season.

hits.name: Barre Bike Path and Corridor Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Barre Town Forest – Millstone Trails Association
hits.description:
Barre Town Forest is a 370-acre park located on the property of an old granite mine. The mine was established in 1790 and was operational for over 100 years. Today, the area is reclaimed for recreational use. Begin on the bike path before detouring onto the Corridor Trail. It will rejoin the bike path and head back towards the school.

Hunting is permitted, so remember to wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.

hits.name: Misty Meadows, Riverside, Mid Way, Cut Thru, and Meadow Lark Trail Loop
hits.description:
Hikers are asked to park in the lot closest to Brookside Drive during school hours. There is an informational kiosk near this parking area.

The trails enter the woods, through an open area then along Browns River. The trail then begins to head back towards the school along Rodgers Brook and the perimeter of a field before arriving back at the parking area.

hits.name: Mainline, Vast, Capital, Serenity, Corridor, Heifier Pasture, Link, #6, and Westside Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Barre Town Forest – Millstone Trails Association
hits.description:
Barre Town Forest is a 370-acre park located on the property of an old granite mine. The mine was established in 1790 and was operational for over 100 years. Today, the area is reclaimed for recreational use. The trails wind through the woods and above the quarry ponds.

Hunting is permitted, so remember to wear blaze orange during hunting seasons.

hits.name: Pond Loop
hits.description:
This section of trails in the Windridge Trail system is known as the West Farm Road Trails.

The Pond Loop is mostly wooded and passes closely by a large field. In the second half, the loop passes by a pond near Canyon Road. This is a fun, mostly flat trail that is perfect for pets and visitors of all ages.

hits.name: Loggers and Seeley Hill Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Windridge Trail system is located a short distance from the town center of Jeffersonville.

Begin walking along the perimeter of an open pasture, and then enter the dense forest. The trail climbs up towards Seeley Hill and then continues a loop heading back towards the trailhead off of Canyon Road.

hits.name: Hinton, Dine, Hannum, and Beaver Pond Trail Loop
hits.description:
This loop passes through the forest and wetland areas. Keep an eye out for birds, deer, beavers, and other woodland animals.

The area is managed by the Putney Mountain Association which works to protect the Windmill Ridge area in southeast Vermont.

Drones are not permitted in areas managed by the Putney Mountain Association.
